review_content: Taking account that the purpose of beer has changed from what actually tastes like beer to what has the highest hop bite, this is slightly above average. An old timer like me still enjoys a refreshing, clean tasting beer like Miller High Life.

I seldom buy American beers, and this one is not the best. Their claim that it is the Champagne of beers made me squirm. Only real champagne can be called Champagne nothing else. The only plus is the low alcohol content, suitable for a hot sunny day.

This is one of those main stream beers that everybody drinks.  I have not had one of those in a long time due to my craft beer addiction.  Flavor was ok full potent flavors with an ok finish.  Decent beer.

Used to quaff this American classic back in 60’s snd 70’s - even in 50’s when the folks would buy it in returnable bottles by the case. Got to share one with  my brother Saturday night.  So I had to try it again. 16 ounce can pours clear amber with foamy head that lasts in my copper stein!. Nothing overwhelming about aroma or mouth feel here. Crisp and refreshing and better than some of the other AAL’s out there. I actually liked it. The price is right too! Prosit!

Every extremely low review needs to get off their HIGH horse. Locally this beer cost's $10 for a 12 pack. At that price point to act like you're going to get something amazing is ludacris. Drink it knowing that it costs less than a dollar US for 12 ounces. Okay now that I've got that off my chest. FOR THE PRICE it is not bad, a great hot day or party beer.

Has a crisp barnyard flavor. Like manure or chicken droppings. I’ve tasted many beers from Milwaukee and this is one of the best. A good balance between hops and grains, quite Sandy but fine grained. Most craft beer drinkers are full of shit anyway. Craft beers all taste like shit. Try drinking a good beer, Miller High Life forever.

Very good compared to the other big-name macro brews (Budweiser, Miller Lite, Coors, etc.), but that doesn’t make it a good beer. It’s drinkable, but not satisfying. No reason to buy this when you can usually find a 6 pack of something from a brewer like New Belgium for $8 or so.

Pours clear, lasting foam. Smells like grains and a surprisingly clean finish for a macro. Good cheap beer for a Sunday bbq or to refresh yourself after a hot summer day cleaning the backyard. Not as watery as other "popular" brands. Very good deal for such a low price.

For what this beer is trying to do (I.E be a beer that tastes like beer) it works incredibly well. It's a straightforward lager that refreshes and goes down easy with practically any food you can think of. Don't let the snobs here fool you. Your beer doesn't have to taste complex or carry some imaginary credibility to be enjoyed. As long as it tastes alrite, I'm alrite.🍺 Stay safe y'all.

473ml can. Pours a crystal clear gold with a small, foamy, long lasting, white head that laces. Faint aroma of grainy malt and corn. Sweet flavour of grainy malt, corn and grass in a crisp, clean finish. Light body with a thin, watery texture and average carbonation. Take Back the High Life? I wonder if they mean you need to get "High" in order to enjoy this?

ReRefreshing
 frebbbbsumeRefreshing this is definitely a summer beer with added Sweet tarde in the backs
Bottle beats can. A strange sweetness far in the back. Great value. Clean and refreshing.
No frills perfect after work beer. Can’t beat the price. Many people don’t care for it but for me no headaches and I love the taste.
Can, pours a piss yellow with a small white head. Aroma is nonexistent, with cheap adjuncts. Flavour is at least clean, with cheap adjuncts, straw and corn. Lame stuff.

Pours a crystal clear gold color with a white head and very good retention.  Very good lacing too.  Almost no aroma. Sweet and lightly grainy lager flavor. Clean and crisp mouthfeel. Classic American beer for the first beer of the decade. Happy New Year!

Taking account that the purpose of beer has changed from what actually tastes like beer to what has the highest hop bite, this is slightly above average. An old timer like me still enjoys a refreshing, clean tasting beer like Miller High Life.

Bottle beats can. A strange sweetness far in the back. Great value. Clean and refreshing.
No frills perfect after work beer. Can’t beat the price. Many people don’t care for it but for me no headaches and I love the taste.
Can, pours a piss yellow with a small white head. Aroma is nonexistent, with cheap adjuncts. Flavour is at least clean, with cheap adjuncts, straw and corn. Lame stuff.

Pours a crystal clear gold color with a white head and very good retention.  Very good lacing too.  Almost no aroma. Sweet and lightly grainy lager flavor. Clean and crisp mouthfeel. Classic American beer for the first beer of the decade. Happy New Year!

People can trash this beer all they want, but for what it is, I absolutely love it. It's a classic American blue-collar lager and it's a crisp refreshing beer. Decent sweetness, light bitterness, decent body, nice pale golden color. I've gotta say it's probably my favorite macro brew.

Not everyone enjoys Coco or grapefruit or God knows what else brewed into their beer. As far as cheap American beers go this is one of the better offerings.

It's tasty cold and is affordable. Goes down smooth and tastes fine with food. We aren't from your country so some of your beers taste pretty piss poor to us as well. Just throwing that out there. My beer doesn't need to feel like I just ate an entire meal after drinking one. 

This beer is great cold after mowing the lawn or a hard day at work. This is naturally a light beer anything lighter and you might float away.

[An attractive 12oz glass bottle, bought at Albertson's, Fullerton, CA.] A bright straw coloured pour with a tight white head; disgusting aroma - like a cat being sick in a bowl of cornflakes; sweet, watery and tasteless in the mouth. Presumably drinkable when chilled to within an inch of its life - but otherwise not.
Some things should have been left alone! Down right gross,  terrible tasting beer that was once my go to after work beer.  SUCKS
Pale yellow with heavy fizz.  Has a slightly different  American lager taste than other mass market lagers.  Corn tase with bitter aftertaste.  Just a little off.
I drank this beer when I was 18, years later, I got headaches from Budweiser, and I went back to Miller, no problems, in fact I buy it for my kegerator now!!
Lager with no frills. Made for times when "just a beer" is needed or appropriate.
Very nice beer! This is the kind of beer that is a good beer to drink, when you want to drink a good beer. I reccomend drinking this beer, highly!🍺

Miller High Life is probably the best of the "cheap American beer" category. People look down on them because, admittedly, there are tons of craft beers that are objectively better. That being said, there is no denying a nice, crisp, easy drinking macro beer is very enjoyable to most people. Miller High Life is inoffensive, clean, and has an actual flavor to it. It won't win any awards for bold flavor, but it is a clear highlight in the category in which it resides. Easily my favorite macro beer.
My favorite mass produced beer, slightly sweet, non offensive, well balanced. I could drink this all day.

Miller High Life is not a small batch 'craft beer', and doesn't pretend to be.  It's a mass produced beer made for, well, 'the masses'.  It has a slightly sweet grainy flavor, with a touch of hops, and just a hint of bitter on the end.  For me, it's refreshing on a hot day, and goes great with pizza, tacos and popcorn.  It's also easier on the wallet.  

A couple of reviewers mentioned it tasted like piss.  I'll have to take their word for it, since I've never tasted piss.
A good balance of malty and watery. Visited the brewery in Milwaukee. Better than miller lite.

See, the thing that most people fail to consider, is the price, and the history. Does High life stack up to some of the IPAs around now? Of course not. The recipe for high life was invented before our great grandparents were even born. And on top of that, at 1 dollar for a 24OZ can, it's pretty much the best in it's class. There is no other beer *in this price range* that can compare whatsoever. And even a little over as well. No, this beer will not knock your socks off, but typically the brews that do are 4-5 bucks a pop. Is high life the champagne of ALL beers? Of course not! Is it the champagne of beers (in it's class)? Absolutely.

In a world of hipster IPA's, this beer is a refreshing, easy drinking, not bitter American Lager... simple. Sometimes it's just fine to sit down and enjoy the mellow, smooth, unpretentious lighter flavor of Miller High Life. If it was bad like many of the reviewers here have said, I very much doubt it would have stayed in production since 1903. Enjoy it for it's own tradition and don't go at it like it's failing to be one of the over-hopped micro-brews of the week. Some of us just don't pretend.
Tastes like ‘beer’ in the same way hotel paintings look like ‘art’; it’s what it says it is, without being anything groundbreaking or special

Clear pale gold with thin foamy white head
Aroma is mild grain
Flava is light malt grain
Feels light with lively fizz
Finishes mildly bitter
Pale golden with a white head - Hints of malts in the aroma - Malt body with hardly any bitterness - Thin malt finish - This was boring
Champagne of beers, well not quite. However it was a nice thirst quencher more similar to Mexican lager beers than the average Miller or Bud... and that is a good thing indeed.
Malt, very slight hops, grass.  Very drinkable and refreshing.  Seems like a huge bargain when similar Mexican beers that all taste the same are now over $1 per bottle.  My go to on a hot day.
Very pale, very clear, white head. Malty, sweet fruitiness, corn smell. Some hops maybe. Dry, malt, grain taste. Very drinkable.
Clear, watery yellow colored, medium- white head. Light malt, lots of corn, some grain, light grassy bitterness, hay. Light bodied, soft carbonation, too watery. Bland and watery...

I love pale lagers and pilsners from all over, but this one taste like piss.
Very strange taste, not to my liking.
Keep spending on craft beer but this is just old dependable American , younger days preferred pbr but this is my go to now
pale yellow, lots of fizz.  stale aroma.  flavours of corn syrup and stale straw.  cheap and plentiful, so it is what it is I guess.

This is the champagne of beers if you are used to drinking Natty Light or Milwaukee's best but for me its total rubbish. Piss color and a piss taste. bad florals, grain, and malt. Drain pour all the time.
Light pilsener taste, refreshing carbonation. Hot weather beer, alternative to corn syrup Corona.
Nothing remarkable, but a quaffable beer at a decent price.  Very typical American lager.

I have drank a lot of light beer and highlife always stands out. It’s very drinkable, it taste good, and it’s cheap. You can’t beat it. I keep a fridge full to all my highlife brothers and sisters out there. Keep on keeping on.
Light watery and consistent. It's not a great beer but for the price it's definitely a good easy drinking beer. Try with a side of Bourbon

Big Bottle from the liquor store in Moss Landing on a depressing evening - you can guzzle that one easily, which was good. not much taste. but whats with that smell? horrible! like ssome threw up in the elevator!

12oz can. Drank from can. Peach, synthetic white grape, bit of grain, big hit of generic fruity candy. Not much body. The fruitiness is not a pleasant one, but it hides any of the usual lager flaws and makes this somewhat drinkable. Not convinced by the champagne comparison though.

5/8/19 (Chicago): $5 draft pitcher poured into pint glass at Edison Park Inn. Clear thin blond straw pour, light white head and lacing. Nominal corn aroma and taste. Thin mouthfeel clean crisp drinking, easy drinking. Overall good pour.
My favorite beer easy to drink miller light is kinda to dry for me so miller high life is where it’s at this is my go to and for the price it’s honestly not bad

I'm not a beer drinker, nor ever really LIKED beer
..I drank it for utilitarian purposes. When I discovered Miller High Life, I realized that beer can be enjoyed like any other drink. Who cares about "flavor profiles" or "old man beer" snobbery. I'm an old man, and when I want a beer, this is the beer.
I drink 48 beers a week and its always miller.  The price is amazing and the beer is so so smooth.
As a professional beer drinker, I like my High Life in what else?, a Champagne Flute. NEVER NEVER EVER CHANGE IT TO KEEP UP WITH TRENDS!

L Yellow somewhat champagne like, decent head
S Corn 
T Taste like corn syrup, primarily pretty flavorless
F Carbonation balances out corn sweetness pretty well
Overall compared to budlight or Coors not to shabby, decent lawnmower beer I guess.

This was the 2018 champagne bottle version . The Aromas are unusually sweet malty bread dough. Flavors are like nose, sort of like taffy flavored beer thankfully with good carbonation to balance the sweetness. Been a long time since I've had one of these and hopefully at least as long until I have another.
A very smooth and easy drinking beer. Very refreshing on summer days after yard work. I pick it up from time to time. Cheers.
Not as bad as I was expecting. There's a definite grainy component that leads to a standard lager finish. Rather light.

Ok; in today's world of craft and variety, this is typically regarded as horrible beer. I prefer to think of it as a decent lawn mowing beer. You know what you're getting, corn and water. I appreciate what one of the other reviews pointed out; the finish is noticeably different/better when you guzzle. I remember drinking beer when the legal limit for beer was 3.2%. You wouldn't want to chug a 7.2 IPA on a hot summer day after working outdoors all day; maybe that has something to do with the crappy flavor profiles of the big guys who survived the prohibition period. A watery low alcohol beer to chug after sweating all day, that's what this beer is. It's not something to sniff, sip, swirl, swallow. It's a dinosaur which walks among us, and I personally like it for what it is. But then, I'm a boomer.

What the heck - when in Rome... Pours clear straw golden with a two finger, white head.  Aroma is corn and faint hops. Taste is corn syrup, moving to a hint of hoppiness. Finish is nondescript. The definition of empty calories.

A personal favorite. My go to. Not the most popular and referred to often as old man beer, it's a must in my fridge. A bit rough to swallow to the unfamiliar, but the ginger ale like tingle and uncontrolable foamy head truly makes Miller High Life the champagne of beers.

A 32 oz can of Miller for a pre-concert tuneup. It has been a while since I have had one. Nice and cold certainly, drink from the can. It tastes of corn slightly, grain and water. Eh, here we are, not much to get excited over. Bring on the music.
The beer is just bland. One of my first underage beers. Tried it 40 years later and glad I outgrew it

A single tall can from 8th St Liquor store in New Westminster. A pale golden beer with a generous white head and a faint sweet nose of..corn? I think so. If one sips slowly as I’m used to do, the taste is weak and insipid throughout, with a trace of bitterness on the finish. That clearly is not the way to drink this beer, so by guzzling a few ounces straight from the can I actually noticed some passable hop bite in the finish. Interesting. This is not a beer to be sipped, but guzzled, and frankly, the colder the better. 2

An authentic, nostalgic, true American classic.  

The beer has gorgeous color, highlighted by that beautiful crystal clear bottle and great retro style label... and a timeless slogan to match: “If you’ve got the time we’ve got the beer.”  Guys, for this one, I’ll make the time.

When it’s ice, ice cold it’s absolutely magical, like french kissing a unicorn under a rainbow... the instant it gets a little warm it turns right into dragon piss... so best to enjoy it in the hard to find 7 oz. shorty bottle so you can quaff it down quickly before your hand warms the bottle.

Perfectly pairs with a dog, burger or a Taco Bell beefy, cheesy bean burrito... but as a word of caution, it’ll absolutely destroy a wonderful Chocolate Millefueille Les Pres Eugenie.

Still, for all it’s faults,  it’s truly one of my faves.

I find for the price of this beer in my area being a semi-cheaper beer. It is actually very decent for its price range why im giving it the score I did. Not the best beer out there but good for the price compared to some major brands.

Pours and taste is excellent. A little too foamy. Overall a quality beer, at a very surprising low price. Not too strong or too week. Not too bitter or bland. Beer as it should be. Very refreshing and drink ability

Been comparing less expensive beers for several months and Miller High Life is THE BEST. The market share comeback is not just 20 somethings channeling classic rock and their father’s beer, it’s the sweet, crisp and mildly bitter taste, the way the bubbles rise up the mini champagne bottleneck, and the crisp, clean, ballsy clear-bottled, carbonated, don’t drink me warm goodness.  It’s probably the corn hints and corny, carbonated malt taste that distances this very good beer from its rivals, and anyone craving a break from the perfectly acceptable super and pseudo intellectual IPA universe. Don’t be ashamed just like or love it.

Regardless of what the "finer palates" and all of the beer snobs say- this beer is stalworth. Miller is "dirty" beer- the head is thick and creamy and it hangs onto the glass until the bitter end. Ice cold on a hot day and I will take a high life over any other cheap beer.

Picked up a tallboy at LCBO. Pours a massive foamy white head that sticks around for quite awhile and has a straw coloured appearance. Big thick dirty lacing. Aromas of grains, grass and subtle wheats. Flavours are sweet malt, grains, herbal and grassy notes. Somewhat excessive carbonation. Dry finish. Fairly bland overall.

473ml can. Pours a clear, golden yellow with a finger of head that things to a thick coating that leaves some mild lacing. Aroma has notes of sweet grains, slight creamy caramel, and traditional earthy/spicy hops. Taste is balanced. Starts with sweet grains, then gets a touch spicy, then ends with some bready/biscuit malts. Medium body and carbonation. Clean in the mouth with a dry finish. Overall a beer most people wouldn't be offended by.

American lager, 4.6%

Eye: six inch head disappears after about a minute. Looks like corn.

Nose: Corn, light hops, green apple, wet earth, mushroom. Something like motor oil hangs out in the back.

Tongue: Corn, green apple, peach, earth. A displeasing bitterness keeps hanging on subtly, almost more mouthfeel than flavor. Strong carbon mouthfeel.

Notes: I'm fairly surprised by the level of complexity here. It really, really doesn't suck, and actually makes me think of watered down apple juice. The odd automotive notes (which I imagine to be from adjuncts) aside, the flavors really aren't bad... Just subtle. This is a tasty, easy sipping beer if ever there was one, better enjoyed from a can than a snifter but holding up to scrutiny surprisingly well.

82/100
I am not a beer snob, as I enjoy trying a variety beers. However, I like lagers, pilsners and kolsch style beers the most. High Life is surely at the top of my list for American Lagers!

I’ve drank a ton of different beer. Microbrew IPAs across America, alt-bier in Düsseldorf, Pilsners in Plzen, lagers in Munich and cask ales in myriad London pubs. All delicious. Given all that beer tasting, I have to say that living the High Life isn’t too shabby. It’s a great beer on a hot day during a barbecue or even if you’re just sitting outside watching the world go by. Not the best beer I’ve ever had, but far from the worst. It’s crisp, smooth with a little bite at the end. Enjoy it extra cold and preferably from a bottle. The cans get a little tinny. The High Life gets a bad wrap from other beers snobs.

i didn't used to like it when i was younger. i tried it again, its been 22 years later now, and i can say that i like this beer alot. it does have a corn and slight wet grain aroma. it is very smooth going down. it has a very light golden appearance. not too much head. very kind at the bottom of the bottle. i will definitely make it my go to for a back yard BBQ. very good for the low price.

Blast from the past, 7 oz. Pony bottle. Wish more breweries would do this. And the beer is not horrible.  Clean, grainy aroma and taste,  even a small bite at the end. A bit weak perhaps, but not bad for a macro lager.
Crappy version of miller lite. Not even worth going into specifics about the taste and palate. Not terrible but certainly not worth paying for.
Screw the snobs this is some damn good beer, the High Life is the only way to live!
946ml Dose. Klar und golden mit mittelgroßer Schaumkrone. Leicht getreidig. Sehr wässrig. Etwas Malz. Sonst ist nichts schmeckbar.

The taste between 2 cans of the same batch is inconsistent. The first can tasted OK, there's really nothing special about this beer, it's one of the cheapest beer you can find around. The second can tasted harsh, and every other can tasted different too. Not normal for such a high production kind of beer, they clearly have issues with their production / recipe.

Can.  It pours a clear gold with a  disipating white head that retains a thin cover with ample carbonation bubbles.  The aroma and flavor are corn grain, while the taste is sweet. It has a clean finish.
I have no idea where the negative reviews are coming from, its a very crisp beer, smooth going down, very minimal after taste, one of my favourite beers.
Can. Clear pale yellow body, big white head with decent retention and some lacing. Aroma of corn, wet grains, cardboard and boiled eggs. Taste of rice, malt, crackers and mineral water. Ok.
Can. Cheap. Did the job. Drank this for decades but never reviewed it. Go Cavs!

Taste- crisp finish light, some would say watery,some grains typical for American style.

Smell- smells like a beer, very mild smell

Finish-smooth as water, great for hot days

Absolutely one of my favorite beers!

Open a chilled bootle and then poured into an ice cold beer glass...mmm... smooth...perfect taste for a hot summer day or when your'e very, very thirsty....goes down smooth...you'll want more after you've satisfied that thirst...it's all good, baby....

First beer I ever really binged on. It's nice and cheap for 24 packs. The taste is a bit gross at first; but after the second or third beer, it's barely noticeable. Has a distinct yellow color that is complemented further by the bottle it comes in.

From can poured into pils glass.  Straw orange colour with one finger head that lingers.  Taste of dough/biscuit and barley with crisp finish and a slightly bitter after taste.  Body is light-medium. This beer must be rated within its own category of American Adjunct Lager.  For this style it is a decent beer.  Served icy cold it is a refreshing summer beer alongside a cheeseburger!

473 ml can. Clear golden yellow, fading white foam. Grainy pukey lager malt smell. Grainy lager malty slightly sweet taste, the epitomy of American industrial swill, certainly not worth writing a novel about. Average carbonation, light bodied, lightly hopped. LF (Lagerboy Friendly) ™️
Dégustée le 2018-08-18.                                                                                                                                                  .

24 ounce can into lager glass, best before 5/14/2018. Pours crystal clear medium golden yellow color with a 1 finger dense and rocky white head with awesome retention, that reduces to a nice cap that lingers. Nice spotty soapy lacing clings down the glass, with a fair amount of streaming carbonation. Fantastic appearance. Aromas of cracker, corn, white bread dough, lightly toasted biscuit, light pepper, and herbal/grassy earthiness. Nice and pleasant aromas with pale malt/corn and light earthy hop notes; with solid strength. Taste of cracker, corn, white bread dough, lightly toasted biscuit, light pepper, and herbal/grassy earthiness. Light herbal, grassy, spicy bitterness on the finish. Lingering notes of cracker, corn, white bread dough, lightly toasted biscuit, light pepper, and herbal/grassy earthiness on the finish for a good bit. Nice robustness of pale malt/corn and light earthy hop flavors; with a great malt/bitterness balance, and zero cloying/astringent flavors after the finish. Moderately crisp/clean finishing. Perfectly clean on lager flavors, with zero yeast notes present. Lightly increasing dryness from lingering bitterness. Medium-high carbonation and light-medium body; with a very smooth, moderately bready/grainy, and lightly sticky mouthfeel that is nice. Zero warming alcohol as expected of 4.6%. Overall this is a good pale adjunct lager style. All around good robustness of pale malt/corn and light earthy hop flavors; very smooth, crisp, clean, and refreshing to drink. Flavorful and never watery feeling for the ABV. Despite having corn there isn't a ton in there, plenty of barley character. Clean malt/grain flavors and solid earthy hop presence. A nicely enjoyable offering, and great style example.

This maybe should be rated lower for beer over all, but for the style of American Style Adjunct Lager, this rates near perfect on the scale. The appearance, aroma, and taste, is in league with what this represents itself as. Another victim of people not understanding the style of beers they rate.

3/10/18
W/ A eating reverse-seared flank steaks and sautéed green beans. 

Poured from can. Clear bubble straw with a quickly dissipating fluffy white head. 

Nose is sweet Pilsner malts and adjuncts. 

Taste is warm Pilsner/biscuit malt with a hint of metallic hops. Quite sweet with a hint of bitterness. Lots of bread/biscuit malt flavors. Quite flavorful for what it is. 

Palate is medium-light and very carbonated. I️ guess this is where it gets the “champagne of beers” moniker. 

Overall, this is great for an AAL. Very malty and flavorful. I love lite and this tastes very similar with maybe a little more fullness. Perfect beer with a steak dinner.
Go fuck yourself. I live the high life. Champagne of beers forever. Wish they sold it in Canada!

Beer 1300! For laughs!

Aroma - corny malt mixed up with grassy hops.
Appearance - clean pale body. White head that is good and gradually rings out.
Taste - dominant taste is stale grassy hops some undesirable malt going on.
Palate - body is light, texture is average, carbonation is lively, finish is gassy and grassy.
I like this beer. Its simple. Not fancy. Or a skunk beer. Bottle form is the best. Can form is not very good.. Taste metallic and has bad after taste.

Pours clear straw, big white head. Aroma is very typical for the style, lightly grass apple malt. Only very subtle hints of corn. More canned corn in the taste, barely detectable and bland hops. Pretty light. Better than this brewer's "lite" beer, perhaps better than Budweiser, but still far from the champagne of beers.

This beer? poured a clear yellow colour with a minimal white head. No lacing. Scents include cat pee, perm solution, corn and sod water. First swig was probably the most watery beer I’ve ever had. Other flavours of corn, honey and light malt.  Finish is malty with honey lingering.

12oz can, living the high life for Christmas '17! Nose relatively inoffensive, whiff of corn and lightly floral, lightly metallic. Pour clear, dull golden with big bubbles and a soapy bright white head that's about as ugly as they come and even spiderwebs. Taste medium-sweet with low bitterness, corn, metal, but actually has a pleasant yeasty-graininess and none of the astringent-hangover notes common to style. Still feels stripped, like it was passed through a series of increasingly finer filter. Low perfume-floral, medium body is heavy with medium carbonation, ultimately fine. Appreciate the notable absence of strong booziness, it's soft and almost delicate. [2017.12.25: 1.9]
473ml can. Clear golden with a foamy white head. Flavors are cardboard and corn syrup with herbal and spicy notes. Medium body, moderate carbonation, slick texture.

Not the best beer in the world, but probably my favorite or 2nd favorite Macro Lager. It's got a sweet hint to its initial touch on the tongue. I get this one regularly actually 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Combination of taste and value unparalleled. Not a fancy sipping brew, this is a smooth, crisp beer made for drinking. My beer of choice, but much better in bottles than cans.golden, minimal head, light body, lively,
Bottle. Clear golden color, white head. Aroma has malts. Pure malty taste, clean. Pretty ok lager, no bad flavors.

an average brew that has little taste or flavor to speak of.
it is not bad, so many drink it 
it is not great, so why brew it?

From Oct 2007

This pours from 24oz can a clear light gold with a small head of foam that dissipates to nothing almost immediately. Ok, the second pour had a bigger head of foam but it still shrank quickly but it's leaving a few island this time.

The smell is a strong whiff of corn.

The taste is a strong corn flavour and some sweet malt that is followed by some hop bitterness that stays right through the finish. Not very complex, duh, but it still tastes pretty good to me but not as good as I remember it from several years ago. There's certainly nothing offensive here and it makes for a good thirst quencher.

PS: I actually enjoyed this brew on tap in the past but it seems no one carries the draft anymore. At least, not in my area.

Sample at the brewery. It poured a clear golden color with a white head. The aroma was of grain, corn and malts. The taste was similar to the aroma with more grain, corn, malts and medium carbonation. After taking the tour, have a better appreciation for their beers.

12 oz can at Taco Republic in Kansas City, Kansas. Ordered as a “mystery beer”. The pour is crystal clear golden, with visible carbonation bubbles and a thin white head. The aroma is grain, corn, and softly sweet cracker malt. Clean, though muted. The taste is straightforward grain / corn sweet malt. Clean, until it warms a bit, then becomes a bit muddled. The palate is light bodied, coarse carbonation and sweet lingering malt finish. Typical macro.

Looks can deceiving. I watched the new commercials and thought I would give it a try. Tried it out and was very disappointed.

Bottle at the Spotted Cat. Clear golden liquid with small to medium white head. Aroma corn, grain, bread and metal. Taste is very light sweet and light bitter with notes of grain, bread and corn. Light to medium bodied with medium to high carbonation. Ok logger.
Can. Pours a sparkling golden color with medium-sized white head and lively carbonation. Actually holds a head. Mostly grainy aroma. Single note sweet flavor. Thin bodied. Not the worst fizzy beer.

Thick white head on top of a clear yellow body.  There's a subtle aroma of earth, nothing to really smell. Burly on the palette. It tastes like a good beer made with cheap ingredients. There's a mildly foul aftertaste but probably the best of the macro brewery beers.

Nectar of the gods, poured from the hand of Zeus and delivered to you my friend. Drink and drink well my friends. Beautiful clear gold with a large white head. Grainy aroma, more adjunct smelling than malted barley. Clean light, dry malt/corn flavor. Minimal bitterness. Perfect for a heatwave, but otherwise not much going on here.

From old tasting notes. Pale gold color. Rocky white head. Sour fruit malt aroma. Light crisp dry malt flavor. Highly carbonated. Very light body and flavor.

What’s not to love about the classic American Pilsner? 


Miller. High Life, in a bottle. The champagne of beers. 

In spite of the classic tag line, it’s not a pretentious beer. In fact if beer could be blue collar union worker, Miller High Life would be that beer. 



A sharp first taste, almost tart. After few sips the sweetness of the corn mellows out the sharp flavor yet stays light, effervescent. 



And for the love of God, drink it ice cold. This is not a beer that remains drinkable at room temperature. 8)  



This is the macro beer that you don’t have to be embarrassed to be seen holding. Because anyone who’d sneer at a beautiful clear bottle of fizzy yellow gold Miller High Life? Well that’s just not the sort of person you should be trying to impress anyway. 



Just listen to the song. Hear Johny Mack on the piano keys, tinkling lightly? 

***

“If you’ve got the time / we’ve got the beer (Miller beer) 
Miller tastes too good to hurry through / but when it’s time to relax / Mil-ler stands clear (beer after beer) 
If you’ve got the time (if you’ve got the time) / we’ve got the beer (Miller beer).” 

***

That tune? It sounds exactly like Miller High Life, in a bottle, tastes.
When you are looking for a good fade on a hot day. You are short on cash but want to get trashed...the champagne of beers baby.
Bottle sample at a tasting at Tom L’s place. Thanks Tom L. Indian version, 5%. Clear yellow. Grains, acetaldehyde, some corn, vegetal, sweetish, bitterish, light-bodied.
At Tom’s Place, pours pale yellow with a small head, aroma of grain, malty, corn, flavor of corn, malt, toast, light bodied
The champagne of beers is actually a very favorable alternative to bud or mmiller sweet malt profile and corn in the finish.

12 ounce can. Pours a very clear light yellow with a white head. Miller uses a foam enhancer called propylene glycol alginate in its beers so you really cannot judge the foam retention. The aroma is nice and clean, the taste is very sweet and there is a good deal of flaked corn aftertaste. All in all, a very good example of a pale American lager. Served cold, this is a refreshing beverage.

Aroma: corn
Appearance:golden, clear, white foam, medium head 
Taste: lightly bitter, 
Palate:light body, thin feel, lively carbonation, refreshing

(Bottle, Hotel Vivanta by Taj, Gurgaon, 12 Nov 2016) Pale golden colour with brief, white head. Malty nose with notes of cereal and hay, not much more. Malty taste with white bread, cereal, hay and a touch of citrus. Hardly any bitterness. Medium body, with a touch of sweetness. No off-flavours, but thin, hollow and fairly pointless.

This is the best beer. It’s my favorite, and I like to drink it. I would drink high life on a plane, I would drink high life in the rain. I would drink high life in the bar, I would drink high life near or far. I would drink high life here or there, I would drink high life anywhere.

The beautiful golden color, paired with the delightful fizz makes for a combination that cannot be beaten.

Highlife is good with supper, good while watching the Packers, good in the yard, good for chasing a shot of tequilla, and very good when paired with more high life.

100/100 best beer. Anyone who says otherwise is wrong.

God Bless
-Ye Walruss
I like getting this beer in the bottles. It has a great taste and goes well with meals.
Bière très bonne et qui se bout comme du sirop. Une pure merveille! Sa couleur d’un jaune quasi fluo est assez particulière et rarement vue.

(12oz bottle, Virginia USA)
(original rating of 1.9 given on Jan 14, 2017. Updating on Apr 5, 2019) 
AROMA: almost no nose. (update: light nose of bubblegum and green leafy lettuce and watercress, hint of grain/corn)
APPEARANCE: straw yellow, good carbonation, foamy/oily head that lingers. 
TASTE: touch of sweet corn, white bread/toast, some dairy hints. (update: yep, sweet grain/corn, and creamy dairy, just of touch of roasty malt and some kind of weak hop backbone)
PALATE: a little creamy, slick/watery, not much bitterness or followthru. (pretty light but not ultra light)

OVERALL: a simple and relatively light lager, decent looking with no detracting tastes. Good for having a six pack by the pool or in front of the TV. (yep, nothing bad about it, some flavor and sweetness so you know you're not drinking water, and there actually is tiny bit of a dry malt/hop followthru. Definitely a drinkable beer for hottubs or summer time)

It pours pale yellow with a white fluffy head. It has good clarity, but the head retention is poor. It has a grainy sweet corn like aroma. It has moderate low corn flavor, maybe a slight touch of apple. It has a light body with a high amount of carbonation. Overall there is little taste to this. It is like drinking flavored seltzer water.
Cut and paste all these mass produced beers would have a hard time telling any of them apart

Can, enjoyed in the dining room, soon to be enjoyed in the shower.

The aroma is very mild, it’s lightly sweet with some corn & graininess.



The flavor is on the sweeter end with a very low bitterness. Corny but honestly fairly well balanced. 



This is fine

24 oz. can @ Party Town ’ Florence KY --- Clear medium-light amber color, big frothy (pilsner glass) white head that stays at 1", star fields of lace. My go to summer daily drinking beer; I know, know.
When this Miller is very cold and in a glass bottle, and the temp outside is 100°, and I just finished some yard work, this beer makes it for me.

But I have to admit - I wasn’t disgusted by it and finished it without doing drain pour. It’s good to go back and reflect on the past to really appreciate the craft beer world today.
Quenching that’s it. Big bottle I think 40 oz. got me buzzed. Grains no hops clean but that is it. Not really drinking a beer just drinking some grain seltzer.

Can into a giant pilsner glass. Pale gold that everybody knows. Giant white head that fades in about a minute, as well as the carbonation. Lacing is spotty and odd. 

Only detectable aroma is mold. Starts slightly acidic and finishes slightly sour. Has about as much flavor as water. I might add that this is my go to American cheap beer, but still.... it’s cheap.

A rock-solid thirst quencher and the go-to beer for every post-bowling cool-down session. Most often enjoyed on tap. Anyone else missing High Life guy Windell Middlebrooks? Sorry to see him go so young.
Can - did not pour out of can to look at, aroma and taste just like the cheap pale lager you would think, sweet malt and corn, tasted a lot better 20 years ago in college - go figure! LOL

If you don a top hat, wear a monocle, and are looking for a cheap beer, this is the beer for you! The trademark clear bottle lets everyone know what you are drinking. 12 oz. bottle. Pours clear, with small white head. Aroma of corn, musty. Taste, not very good.

I’ll take it over any Bud, Busch, or Coors any day.
12 oz via can from a friend in KC. Bland, crisp and light. Not completely awful, but kind of gross overall.

On-tap, this pours a clear light yellow color with a foamy white head. The aroma is weak, slight touch of grains and malts. The taste is fairly decent for being a cheap domestic. I’d say a step below Pabst for flavor, then again it probably taste better on draft.
Bottle. Light yellow beer with a white head (when have we seen this?)Light brewing cereal and malt. Quite sweet but there is a bad skunk, maybe from bad brewing cereal or something similar? Ehh
Pass, extremely awful. Watery with a bad taste. I would drink something else if this was the only thing offered.

I am one of those few guys that generally find beer bitter. Miller has a sweet crisp taste. The slight bitterness is at the end. I can easily drink and enjoy this beer. I like it a lot, no matter what anyone else says.

Another one that i drank way to often during college when my budget was minimal...ok beer... Memory rating....(#503)

BREWED AND BOTTLED IN INDIA. Bright gold with a high, fast-diminishing bloom of white. Aroma of teabags, olive oil soap, lemon icing, tinned potatoes and pine needles. Unsettling saline, soluble aspirin and licked stamp flavour with suggestions of burning paper and TCP. Hints of stale conifer, crap bourbon and lemon sponge. Slimy mouthfeel. Got to love that rice and glycerine.

This is now my favorite macro /session beer. It still has the same basic taste that it had 20 years ago. I pray that inbev doesn’t get it’s slimy claws on the Miller brewing company. Inbev has ruined: Budweiser; Rolling Rock; Becks; Bass; Corona and Modelo, just to name a few of it’s victims.
Blech. Served from a can that wasn’t nearly cold enough. Pale lagers only exist to be drunk cold! Skunky, oily, corny, no good.
Pours a clear straw yellowish color. Aroma and taste are grainy and very watery.

Pours a solid straw color. Nice thick head. Lots of lacing as you drink. Very clear, clean, and fresh looking. In my mind, this is what a lager beer should look like.

I’m guessing that’s the cooked vegetable that I smell. I hear people talk about ’cooked vegetable’ and yeah, I guess. Mind you, I don’t consider it ’off-putting’ but it just doesn’t help. Other than that, I can smell mildewed corn. Phhhttt!

Taste, on the other hand is pretty good. It’s pretty mellow. It’s somewhat sweet. I can taste the corn for sure. I taste some decent hops. To me, this is what I expect a beer to taste like, at least in style.

Mouthfeel is medium. It’s full bodied, but not super heavy. It finishes clean, and quite dry. There’s a slight bitterness right at the end of the finish.

Overall, I really like this beer. With the exception of the aroma, this is really good. I think I tend to prefer this beer to be on the warm side. It seems to work better. Good price, for a good beer!!
Pale malts, cardboard, and cereal grains; There really isn’t too much flavor; The only upside is that it’s easy to drink.

From a bottle.
This lager is not too sweet, as some critics say it is, the corn sweetness is not too bad and it’s well balanced with the rest of the ingredients. Forget about the stupid beer logo and slogan "the champaign of beer" I wish MBC would get rid of that slogan already. This is just a good tasting AAL and very low priced.

I am not 100% sure that this is the worst beer out there, there probably are worse. For that reason, until I find something more foul, I won’t give this the bottom of the bottom rating. Sure hope I don’t happen to stumble across any kind of pee-water that is inferior to this. Trying this beer in my earlier years traumatized me for life concerning the Miller Family. I was able to get past those fears, and drank (and actually enjoyed) Miller Genuine Draft/ MGD. Miller Lite..guess if it’s super-cold and I’m mowing a lawn I can drink it....barely. But something about the High Life just makes me feel like I’m living the Low Life.....ugggggg.

I will sometimes grab a 32 ouncer for $2.00 at some of the local stores. This is one of those beers that supposed to be cheap and get ya drunk, but you should just buy malt liquor, it has a higher alcohol level. It might also taste better.
Color of your morning piss, smells like da skunk. Tastes watered down:, bland, boring, and no hints of complexity. Overall, it’s a cheap beer if you wanna drink and not get drunk. But then, why not just drink soda or a water.

16floz can "Artist Series Hydro 74, Long Live The Pursuit, Harley Davidson Edition". Purchased for $ 0.99 at the Shell station in Wilson. Golden hue, normal clarity with mostly lasting fizzy white head. Aroma of corn, wheat and water. Corn and water up front with cat piss taste on the finish. I remember this being better in college when you used to buy these in 40’s, not very enjoyable this time.

Can. Pours very pale yellow with little head. Aroma is yeasty. Not inviting, no color and no bubbles. Aroma is faint but not offensive. Not a lot of flavor but it seems to end better than some other macros with a bit of a hop and a dry finish. The mouthfeel is odd, a little slick at the end. Haven’t had one in 20 years or so and thought I’d give it a fair shake. Not horrible for a macro but not much there for flavor.

Can @@@ some chill party. Gold with a small head. Spiderwebs, white bread, and success. Candy corn. Taste is light and watery. Vread and corn syrup. Eminently crushable if you’re in the mood. Light body, active carb. Doesn’t taste like wolf pussy.
Maybe the best American adjunct lager. No foul tastes, it’s drinkable, not my first choice in session beers but nothing to bitch about.

12oz bottle, poured into a shaker. The aroma is a healthy dose of corn and buttered biscuits with a touch of raw grain. The beer is crystal clear and effervescent with a watery straw, pale hue and a light, airy and foamy white messy head that leaves a thin lace on the glass. The beer is a medium light sweet with a touch of bitter. The watery thin beer has a foamy fizz carbonation, and a light body with flavors of cornbread and biscuit dough. The finish is a light spicy tone with a zip. It’s dry with an aftertaste of cornbread and a touch of lemon.

From iced bottle. Straw colored. A bit hazy, probably chill haze. Weak light body. Nose is almost nothing. A little bit of alcohol. Mouthfeel is watery. Taste is grass and water. Less offensive than similar swill, but still , yuck.

Bottle. Light sugar and corn aromas. Pale gold with thin, quickly dissipating head; substantial lacing. A lot of fine carbonation and some light bitterness up front followed by sweet light malt that is overwhelmed by sugar and a hint of corn. Thin mouthfeel bolstered by high carbonation. Short, smooth, cloying finish.

32 oz. clear bottle. It pours a nice clear light gold color with a surprisingly lasting frothy white head. The aroma has pale malt, creamed corn, light notes of earthy hops. A regular lager to go along with a meal with friends. Not much to point out as good on a rather simple beer.

Appearance: Clear pale golden body, lots of carbonation showing, with a tall and foamy white head that resembles dish soap. This would be perfect if the head wasn’t thin and foamy.

Aroma: Mild sweetness with a touch of caramel, a whiff of corn, and a slight floral hop presence. Rather mild aroma and rather expected.

Taste: Mildly sweet with a hint of caramel and light corn. The finish is dry with carbonic acid. This is refreshing and not watery.

Palate: Medium bodied, moderately high carbonation.

Overall: I used to drink this stuff when I was under the age. I know why I chose it over the light beers now. While it’s not great, it’s definitely a decent macro option and certainly better than any light beer.

Ah yeah, the old "High Life." The champagne of beers. Here we go.
There has been a variety of times this has been poured into pint glasses and pilseners and all of the time, its always the same.
The appearance was a light golden yellow clear color with carbonation rising faster than a speeding bullet (ah, looks like champagne). Anyways, the less than a finger’s worth of white foamy head quickly dies and leaves some lacing that is all over the place and slides right into the body as the beer goes down.
The smell was mostly over cooked sweetened corn.
The taste was mainly the same with adding a terribly dry element to the aftertaste and finish.
On the palate, it sat extremely light and showed a decent sessionability about it. The carbonation tends to assault my mouth fairly harsh.
Overall, well, it wants to be called the "champagne of beers" and since champagne is over-rated, hey why not.

OK, here’s the story. My significant other bought a 40 oz bottle of this brew to boil up some fresh shrimp at the beach and I just had to give it a taste. Truth be told, this one of my favorite beers when I was in high school. Now it just presents itself as another boring pale lager with plenty of sweet corn flavors. Suggest you serve this one at 33 degrees. It really is disgusting at room temperature.

This is basically not beer, as it is full of maize and rice most likely. I don’t want to spend time debating this, it is quite dreadful, but I have fond memories of drinking this at a baseball game and I just want to praise the beer makers for the look of the bottle, the label and the iconic name. Transfer from BA review on 3-13-12 - 
Poured from can into pint glass

Appearance –Pours a medium golden color with a big white head. Big carbonation bubbles could be seen coming up through the brew. The head faded very fast leaving no lacing. 

Smell – Nothing but corn here. 

Taste – The taste is much of the same in the nose. Corn mainly, although there is a slight bit of citrus hop flavor that comes in at the end of the taste. 

Mouthfeel – Thinner body and lots of carbonation. Easy to drink and good for the style.

Overall – Since I paid $1.50 for 32 oz. what should I expect? Slightly subpar in comparison to the standard American adjunct lager.

Pours a pale, transparent straw yellow color, with a fizzy/foamy white head. The aroma is the expected grassy, musty hops over a lightly sweet malt base. The flavor is largely driven by sweet, grainy malts and a bit of a sweet corn character, although the dull, musty hops can be identified as well. As with most in this style, the light body and fizzy carbonation help this one go down easy, but it has more substance/body than others. In this regard, this beer is not much different than the other mass-produced adjunct lagers, but it doesn’t come across as so watery and bland as others. Overall, its a fine beer to wash down a hot dog or any other situation where you just need a dumb beer, but it’s certainly not something to crave and savor.

Appearance: pours a sudsy white 2" head that slowly recedes with some lacing. Plenty of streaming carbonation. Color is clear pale straw.
Aroma: mild aroma of corn sweetness, a bit of vegetable and a hint of lightly toasted barley.
Mouthfeel: very light and watery, somewhat papery with a quite dry finish.

One of the few offerings under the Miller label that I do respect, High Life is an average macro-lager that is mostly just plain sweet adjunct flavored but does finish smooth and clean. I do have some memories of this beer being reasonably refreshing during hot summer days at outdoor family reunions. There is some disconnect between the bubbly appearance and the mouthfeel, which seems relatively flat despite the "champagne" description. Inoffensive, and I actually think this would have more potential if there was even some faint hoppy bitterness in the taste. As it is, a cheap, light, and sweet brew.

I’ve been reviewing beers for about five years now, yet some of the best-selling beers in America I still have not reviewed, like Miller High Life. While not quite the epitome of the macro adjunct lager it’s pretty close since it’s best described as bland. Insert the "making love in a canoe" joke here.



I poured a 24oz can into a 1-liter mug.



Appearance: Clear, gold color with some carbonation initially visible, though it goes tepid quickly. Forms a large, white, fluffy head which mostly dissipates but does leave some lacing on the glass.



Smell: Totally generic "beer" smell, though on the cleaner and less offensive side. Some corn notes, but otherwise odorless.



Taste: You’d think after all these years of drinking craft beer and refining my palate that I’d be able to pick up on the genuine flavors present in macro adjunct lagers, as subtle as they may be. Though I’m finding the opposite is actually true. As hard as I try, I really can’t find any genuine flavors to Miller High Life. It’s a beer that’s much more bland and flavorless than it is offensive. But simply not being offensive does not a good beer make. 



I think I’d actually prefer the overt rice flavor of Budweiser or the corn flavor of a malt liquor since they give your mouth something to concentrate on. In the case of this beer it’s just a cold liquid with a faint sweetness and a clean finish. Perhaps there’s some canned corn water taste, but there’s definitely nothing in the way of malts or hops. What purpose does this beer serve?



Drinkability: The term "fizzy yellow beer" is a pejorative craft beer nerds use to mock the major macro lagers, but in the case of Miller High Life it’s not even applicable because this beer is not fizzy (which is really ironic considering its tagline of "the Champagne of beers"). It’s bubbly when first poured, but proceeds to go completely flat in mere seconds. It’s slightly refreshing while cold, but that’s hardly a redeeming quality or compliment. I couldn’t find a definite alcohol content on this beer, though most sources seem to peg it at 4.5 - 5.5% ABV (I’m thinking it’s closer to <5%). You’d have no problem drinking it in large quantities, but it will become boring quickly.

24 oz. can poured into a shaker- I wanted to pour this into a Miller High Life pilsner glass that I own (and it is OLD), but after a day from hell- fuck it, just like the high life! Poured an easily transparent thin yellow color, like piss. Huge head formed and laced actually very well down the sides of the vessel, but that head just disappears way too quickly. Aroma of lime and hard water- ugh. Hits the mouth with very light body, the malt has a feel of malt liquor since it’s surrounded by really poor sucrose, middle actually holds, but the finish becomes water with a very tiny bite of hops. Tell your boss she’s a dirty hooker that if you’re not on the dick, you better get off my nuts today- that my friends, that’s the high life!

Sure, most of the time, I like to drink a fine craft beer, but the reality of life is that something I need to think with my wallet a little. Plus, I don’t typically find adjunct lagers necessarily offensive; while there are certainly some terrible ones, sometimes I just want to have a nice cold one. Today, I cooked southwest chicken and wanted something that would get out of the way and refresh me while the spice took over.



Appearance (2/5)
High Life looks like “beer.” It is perfectly clear, sports a shock white head and fades away quickly, and it is a typical light golden color.



Aroma (4/10)
The aroma is fairly sweet, with corn and honey dominating the nose. There might be a faint touch of spice in there somewhere, but it’s hidden. While it isn’t inspiring, I have to compare it to others of a similar ilk, and it stands up in that comparison. It doesn’t smell nearly as “cheap” as some other adjunct lagers.



Taste (10/20)
This stuff is lauded as the “champagne of beers,” but does it have the high quality taste to back up the high quality slogan? Alas, it does not. It is a fairly standard sweet adjunct lager, with corn and pale malt comprising almost all of the taste. There is no discernable hop presence. And there is actually a bit of a bread flavor in the aftertaste, which is fairly pleasant. Overall, it goes down smooth but doesn’t inspire.



Drinkability (4/5)
Where High Life exceeds is in drinkability. This stuff is smooth, doesn’t have any major harsh off flavors, and has a body and carbonation that is made for drinking (which isn’t surprising, considering the fact that this beer clearly wasn’t designed to overwhelm the taste buds). With my spicy chicken and rice, this worked very well. 



Intangibles (3/10)
Miller High Life isn’t a great beer. Hell, it really isn’t even a good beer. But you know what? It’s pretty good for what it is. That said, there’s nothing here that is going to blow you away, and it’s relatively low alcohol, so you need to drink a lot of it to get where you’re going. Then again, it’s like $5 for a six pack of pints at my local grocery store. 



Overall (23/50)

40 oz. bottle. You’ve gotta stop getting me crappy lagers, Jonathan. Pale yellow color with a big, white head. Corn and pale malts, some light resinous hops, and light biscuits. Very sweet. Light body, a little thick and clingy. Overall, this is not as bad as I expected. The aroma is weak, and standard macrobrew malts and hops, but just a little better than the average swill.

How have I never rated this?!  This is my go to non-micro beer.  Honestly, High Life out of a longneck bottle is good with me.  Straw yellow with thin head and corn in the nose.  Nostalgia makes me love this brew though. (But it is a macro lager and tastes only slightly better than them, so I can’t score it too high)

Tallboy can from a gas station because I want something cheap tonight. Pours urine-yellow with a ridiculous head that actually leaves some lacing and is nice and fluffy - props here. Aroma is a big whiff of yeast and skunky hops when you open the can, but mellows to simple corn bread. Taste is water, corn, and aluminum with a weak and dusty pils-hops type finish. Mouthfeel is smooth and drinkable. The hops are a bit stronger than most other beers of its type, but this actually isn’t bad. There are cheaper beers, but I could drink this in a pinch. Good for what it is.
Pours clear gold with a thin white head.  Light straw aroma.  Flavor follows suit...touch of grass.  Mouthfeel is light and the finish is straw and grass.  Simple, clean, boring but not offensive.

Can. LIght grainy malt aroma. Clear gold with a large white head. LIght barley malt flavor. Light body.  I may have given the flavor on this one a little more credit for two reasons 1) I had just tried two different light macros 2) This is the very first beer I ever tried.

Get the 12 oz bottle:  beautiful iconic packaging   I always thought this should be the hipster beer over PBR.  Like Corona and Heinekin, this beer has a clear bottle to allow skunking at your discretion.  I prefer skunked, that way it has *A* flavor.  Unskunked, you taste sweetness and corn, but mostly whatever was already on your own breath.

The worse part is the palate, this beer feels warm even when cold.  The bubbles are too large, it’s burpy-bubbly but not fizzy enough.  And it has the same mouth feel as my saliva.

Oh man, I used to drink this stuff all the time. Pours a very pale yellow, fizzy white head that is gone as soon as it came. Smell has a metallic tang and a bit of corn and hay. Mildly sweet at the beginning, almost a bit of a hay flavor. Not really any bitterness or hoppiness to speak of in the finish. Very carbonated. It’s bland, boring and completely unremarkable, but what else would one expect?

Aroma is mildly malty with a hint of the corn used in the mash. Clear gold in color. Highly effervescent leaving a fine lacing on the glass. Taste is very mild bitterness and clean, dry malt flavor with no perceptible hop flavor. Very thin on the palate if it weren’t so bubbly it would be downright watery. Overall, not as bad as anticipated, not great by any means but not awful.

Pours light as your typical commodity US beer does.  Very carbonated living up to the champpagne side of the title, but not on the classy element.  No hop bitterness or much of a mouth feel to enjoy here.  You should take a hint by the fact that the picture for high life is a 40oz...

Had this beer when i was much younger, but I drank it the other day for the first time in a long time. Aroma is of adjunct grains, perhaps both corn and rice. Taste is very offensive; no smoothness that I’d get from higher quality beers. Champagne of beers? What a joke, this beer is completely the opposite. Just another harsh, tasteless miller macro lager.
Clear, golden yellow and lots of bubbles. Tastes like carbonated watery corn water. Skunky after taste.  Not as bad a some, but worse than many others.
At least it makes nice bubbles.  Not much more to say. Corn skunk smell.  All malt and adjunct flavor.

Pours a clear, pale yellow with a white head.  Aroma is corn and cereal.  Taste is mostly the same, with a bit of a buttery aftertaste thrown in.  Light in body with some lively carbonation.  Pretty basic and generic, but I guess it’ll do in a pinch.
What more can I say? It IS the Champagne of beers. I still need 18 characters.... there

Possibly the worst beer I’ve had outside of the extreme bargain brands. Any sort of taste this beer might have is immediately overshadowed by the repulsive amount of carbonation it boasts. This "champagne of beers" is more like the "sparkling grape juice spiked with cheap vodka" of beers.

This beer is the typical yellow of an American pale lager with the typical white head, and the aroma is also not surprising because of the strong yeast and alcohol smell. The taste is bitter initially, but a sweetness does arise after a little. The palate is interesting for a typical American lager, for it has a medium body, slick texture, average carbonation, and abrupt finish.

I have always been attracted to this beer.Great head,delicious strong corn taste. Beer of the working Joe. Sadly, I have an allergic reaction to corn or strong corn products! So rating this beer is difficult.Rating beer is a very subjective thing to begin with.

So based on my likes, I give Miller High Life a pleasant thumbs up.Wish I could actually sit down to a 6 pack and test the waters.

Homey don’t play dat. i actually have bought this.



corn filled shit. the price is right

Probably the best beer on the market as far as quality vs. value is concerned. Miller High Life is a beer staple that will be on shelves long after everyone who’s reading this review is dead and gone. A blue collared no nonsense beer for the working man on a buget. That’s pretty much been the base audience of Miller High Life. 

I keep this beer in my fridge when my wallet gets a little slim or I just don’t feel like throwing down 15 to 20 dollars for a 6 pack of craft brews. When these bottles are ice cold, they are pretty darn refreshing and pair up weel with pretty much anything for dinner. 

If you like Hootie And The Blowfish, and enjoy wearing turttle neck sweaters, this beer probably won’t be for you.
Bottle.  Pale with bare white head.  Aroma is flat and skunky. Taste is stale and metallic. Unpleasant.

12oz can, best by 12/31/12. Oh my god, this can has got to be compromised. Smells right away like old spilt pale lager and vomit. Tastes acidic and awful. Made me shudder, in a bad way. Actually makes me nauseous. Clear pale yellow color. Big white head. Kind of smooth, lighter carbonation. Light body. Dry texture. Looks and feels not bad, but the taste is an atrocity. Offensively bad. Drain po’ fo’ sho’

Bottle, 33 cl, Goa, India. Clear pale golden with a low bubbly, white head and a very cornish aroma of brewing cereals and rice-cakes. No real taste, no traceable hops, no bitterness. Extremely bland. Hasn’t got shit to with champagne - or real beer for that matter. Give me plain water any day.

Clear straw yellow, short white head. Very sour scent, somewhat earthy like wet dirt and freshly cleaned, damp carpet. Fairly effervescent, thin almost gritty mouth feel. Robust, sour wheaty flavor, also citrusy like lemon juice. Finish is crisp, dry and sour. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

This is a classic sudsy American brew. The color can be a bit off-putting, and it bubbles like champagne. The body is very grainy, lightly hopped, and easy drinking. Best by the pitcher, but good from a long-neck.
Know as the champagne of beers.  I would tend to disagree.  Okay when it’s really hot out, but I would rather drink water.

Can. Light golden, small to average and fully diminishing head. Very light, malty – some corn and sweetish aroma, light alcohol. Body is very light, malty – some corn and sweetish flavor. Finish is very short, malty – some corn and sweetish, light cardboard and light alcohol. High life – low beer.
My regular drinking beer.  Very smooth, has a good taste and no bitter after taste.  Great head - goes down easy.  My favorite beer.

Pours a clear yellow with a never ending white head and much lacing. The nose is light cereal. Palate is light malt up front, corn, and a lingering  medium-light hop bitterness. With the advertising blitz, it now outsells Miller Genuine Draft, which is the same recipe unpasteurized.
UPDATE 9/27/19: I home brew a wide variety including hoppy New England IPAs, which I  love. The MillerCoors lagers  are the best examples of American style lagers. To my palate, they are superior to all the others. Why? There is a malt structure, male sweetness, with a hit of hop bitterness.  Differing from the high flavor profile beers, they are sessionable being 5% ABV and under. Because of their low flavor profile, I have found them useful to train my tasting prowess. To those who think they are showing how sophisticated they are by calling any beer urine are only showing ignorance and snobbery.
For a yard/garage lager does a fine job. Look, smell, taste and mouth feel all simple at best. Price point best feature.

Bottle. Seems strange that I would be drinking this horrible corn-filled lager, especially since I was at dogfish head yesterday. However, after the Atlanta Falcons shutout the New York Giants, it only felt natural to reach for the champagne of beers to help me celebrate. Go Falcons!

Everybody has tried to live the high life. Usually here in Cali that means something else. This golden colored beer is crisp and mild. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

From a bottle to a glass. Pours a crystal clear light gold color with a small frothy head. Aroma is corn malt. Taste follows the aroma with some barley malt nots aswel as a slight earthy hop note in the sip. Medium to light mouthfeel with some fizziness on the tongue. Leaving malt rings all down the glass. Decent malt bill. This is the definition of generic Macro Brewery Beer.

There is a soft spot in my heart for this beer which got me through my poorest periods of college.  The convenience store across the street became my liquor store.  There is a time and a place for American Light Lagers and this, more due to history than flavor, is my beer of choice.  Not particularly good on any level unless you’re on a float trip or something...  Palate is smooth, watery, light bready malts, subtle corn sweetness.  Effervescent.
Looks good and it's very clean. Fun stops there. The champagne of beer flavored water.

Honestly, this looks like carbonated toilet water after a long night at the bar.  Luckily that carbonation stays with you on the way down - a flat high life is a bit like toast without butter; incomplete, archaic, miserable.  With the boost of bubbly and the champaign of beers is the standby go-to for when you want to celebrate... in the dank unfinished basement at your parents place.

This is my favorite cheap American brand-name lager.  I prefer it over Budweiser, Coors, etc.  It like it after it’s been sitting at room temperature 10-15 minutes since it has more flavor.  The other popular American beers are undrinkable unless close to frozen.

One quart beer can poured into a Paulaner liter stein. Lots of foamy head, about a five fingers worth. Maybe the pour was too quick. Golden colored body with only a few bubbles going up. It looked pretty good with all the beer and a think head of foam.
Smell is metallic and white rice. Not great.
Taste is water with white sugar. Not a trace of bitterness to be found.
Kind of fizzy, though only moderate carbonation. Light and sticky body. 
It’s not the worse, but you can to much better.

When you know the guy that enabled the clear bottle, and you drnk it at every eagles tailgate, it's a favorite

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Nothing much to MHL but it is my go to cheapo American lager and it is a feel good drink. Cheap and cheerful.

I tend to prefer corn adjunct to rice - maybe its a fuller body, higher protein residue - but then it is filtered so maybe its just all in my head.  Would be embarrassed to have this in my fridge but probably wouldnt turn one down if nothing else was available.
Nothing offensive here, but nothing really going for it, either. I’m drawn to it only because my grandmother told me she used to drink it 40 years ago as she would do the ironing on hot summer days.

Poured from bottle into pilsner glass. One of the better Macros; it’s actually not too terrible. Pours smooth with very decent head, golden-pale in appearence. There’s a reason they call it the champagne of beers, it is frothy. Strong hints of corn. Very light body with no hoppyness to speak of. Fizzy. 

$8.49 for a 12 pack of bottles is an amazing bargain. For the price, not bad at all. Not a Yuengling or Sammy by any means but for a mainstream beer it drinks well.
Miller’s flagship beer is adequate for what it is meant to be, an inexpensive, high volume beer.

Re-rate (because why not!): Can a month before "drink by" into pils glass, clear pale golden color with a finger of fluffy white head. Aroma notes of pale malt sweetness, slight graininess and faint corniness. Taste adds hints of corn syrup and faint grass/spice hop balance. Light body, moderate-high carbonation, crisp with clean faint bread finish. It is what it is, maybe it offers more fresher but I doubt it.
Classic beer. It?s the champagne of beers, what?s not to like? Cheap and refreshing stuff.

Worst of the worst here. At least Miller has had fun with it calling it the champagne of beers. Contaminated Cook's champagne maybe...

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
16oz can from notes-Pours yellow with a white head. Aroma of corn and sweentess. Taste of the same but a little bit of hops. This light bodied brew IMO was always not too shabby.
Light straw color; Light slightly creamy body; Aroma of cereal, & grain; Flavor of light malt, and hops; Fairly bland and slightly watery; Not terrible for an old macro lager.
Somehow ended up with one of these at the bottom of my cooler after a tailgate.  Exactly as bad as I remember.  At least it’s consistent.
32 oz. can. High corn malt taste. Not much depth. Goes down easy and easily forgettable.
asked a friend who wanted to hang out to bring some beers. he brought two 32oz high lifes.?.. pours yellow. smells bad. tastes bad.
Swill only fit for the saddest of keg parties. Truly the color of what it is.
Spent grain. Rice. Bread yeast. Light malt extract. Smooth, yet ultimately unsatisfactory in both taste and smell. For the style, however, I approve a drink from it from time to time.
rated for numbers only. light, crappy, and over carbonated. maybe a step up from miller lite but still garbage.

Clean, crisp. Not much aroma at all. When one thinks of a "beer". This is it. It goes down smooth, has stood the test of time. I am a micro brew drinker and I still love this beer for the value and drinkability. This is what beer was and will be. Tastes have changed over the years of course. But you can’t beat how fresh this beer tastes. Good bubble count, the colder it is, the better it tastes! Maybe these other people drink it too warm. Let the ice crystals start to form and then drink up!
Good to have on the beach while fishing. Try it with a lime but do not expect the fruit to work wonders. Extremely light and heavy carbed.
Piss yellow with a thin white head. Almost no aroma, I get a little corn. Tastes fine. pretty neutral. Goes down smooth. But it is pretty dull. This is about all I expect out of a miller product.

24 oz can to Sam smith lager glass.One finger head light eggwhite like,plenty of fizzing from the bottom etching. Clear light yellow,thick lacing.
Aroma is grain,corn,a light sweet almost citrus lemon or tartness .Mainly just a mineral typical lager aroma. Slight funk/sulfer.
Taste is light mildly sweet lightly tart smooth med bur more light body- crisp,little bit of chaulk and possibly a very slight grassy hop in there with a bit of citrus finish. Some breadines maybe wheat like.Finishes kinda grainy with a mild sweet corn. Different then i remember it ,and slightly better also.

Poured from a 32-oz. bomber into a pilsner glass at my house on July 31, 2012 (picked it up for 2 for $3.98 at 7/11 in San Diego, Calif., on July 31, 2012). About two fingers of head. Color was basically gold, urine like. Foamy, frothy white head/lacing on the top. Surprisingly good retention on the top and the sides. 

Smelled corn, metallic, wheat, bread, grass. Slight caramel sugar. Heavy cereal. 

Tasted not so much. Got lots of cereal (Cheerios, Shredded Wheat). Corn, metallic, wheat, grass.

Light body. Thin texture. Average carbonation. Abrupt, watery finish. 

Never liked this beer and still don’t like it when rating it. Plenty of better options.

Bottle- Pours a light golden color with a good head that fades to bits of lacing. Aroma of grain, and bits of malt sweetness. Taste of grain and malt sweetness. Decent bitterness and a clean finish. Light body, fairly crisp, smooth and refreshing. Not bad for a macro beer. Could do a lot worse.
I can’t believe that this was my second favorite beer at one time in my life (high school). I had a couple of cans at the local racetrack and it’s pretty nasty!
Tasted as abv 5 % in Bangalore. Slight sour flavor and very slightly bitter. Otherwise not much flavor. Strong yellow in color with a white head.
Clear light yellow pour with a big bubbled white head. Clean crisp grains and a little corn sweetness. Pale lager taste, clean and not terrible.
Better than some of the other cheap alternatives but champagne? Absolutely not. Run of the mill almost flavorless, light, frat boy beer.
12oz bottle yes I did pass on the 4D. Pours out straw yellow topped with a white head. Aroma and taste was the same corn, sweetness, and skunk.
Terrible, but at least it’s cheap. Otherwise it’s just terrible...........................
Ew. Why do they call this the champagne of beers? Its not very good, light and easy to drink, that is all
The beer is a never fail comfort beer. Classy yet trashy. You can’t go wrong with an ice cold Miller High Life!

Tap at the regional US Air Guitar Championship. Poured a clear pale yellowish gold with a large white head that dissipates quickly to the edges. Aroma has a food amount of sweet corn and grains with no discernible hop character. Flavor was similar with sweet corn and grains and not much else.
Well, not too bad... Definitely a miller. Better than most i have tasted from them. Its good tasting for a domestic. But not the best. All i can say is "the champagne of beer" what a crock!!
It comes in a 40 oz option, how good can you expect it to be? This is an inoffensive beer for someone on a budget.

This is good beer.  Poured a beautiful golden color, and created a magnificent mountainous head, which lasted for the whole beer,and laced the glass beautifully.  Great taste, not overwhelming, but refreshing. Decent hoppiness.  This would be a great beer on a hot day with friends.  I read some of the other ratings on this on here.  I had to laugh.  They weren’t drinking this!!  Give it a shot!

Pours a magnificent light yellow with a tight head. No lacing. Overweening full-bodied nose, with hamster cage and pecans. Absolutely disgusting minty flavor, with notes of caramel and lilac. Thick and chewy mouthfeel and very light finish.

Love this beer. Its not great, but its from Miller don’t expect i to be great. Drink it out of the bottle to save yourself from the disappointing aroma. Its crisp, clean and refreshing. Great beer when its 110 degrees out and you decided to BBQ anyways.

Appearance is a light golden yellow supporting a fair head that leaves some lace.  Aroma has mainly grain adjuncts of corn and rice.  Taste again having the grain adjuncts with a faint sweet malt and hop note.  Palate is light with crisp carbonation.  Overall not bad, had worse, one of the better macros.

It’s cold garbage, but I still like it.  And somehow it tastes even better out of the red, white, & blue Americans.  AMERICANS.  Get it?
(bow tie spins, fart noise, exits stage right)

It’s a very simple American style lager.  There’s not that much going on in High Life.   Corn is the only dominant taste.   That said, if you get a fresh batch of it,  it’s an easy and cheap party beer.   Not knowing what I was serving them,  many friends were completely satisfied with it.   It’s got a bad rap as a ghetto beer,  but it’s a simple starter beer.
12 ounce can pour.  Clear yellow color with a light white head.  Not much going on.  Corn and water.

(bottle). First beer for 2012 Memorial Day weekend. A thirst quencher and easy to session for any BBQ or deck party.  Pretty much, an American Corona.   Not high in flavor but clean taste without skunk or bitterness. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Big ol’ 32oz can from the local store. Pours clear straw yellow with a big white head and good lacing. Aroma and tastes of corn, sweet malts and honey. Not as bad as I expected, but I remember it tasting much better when I was 16.

June 2008: Another Miller’s product I had the misfortune to encounter while on holiday in Tobago.

’The Champagne of beers’ my arse!

Clear 12oz bottle of almost clear looking watery liquid which when poured produced no head or aroma what-so-ever.

Why do people buy such tasteless fizzy rubbish? I did, not knowing ’high life’ really means ’low life’ in American brewing advertising. I won’t be making that mistake again.
Poppin’ Champagne ("YEAAAAH BOYYYYY!")!  It’s actually not that bad for a macro, but it’s not that good either.
Pours clear golden yellow, head dissipates and no lacing. Smell is of sweet malted corn. Taste is like any other cheap pale lager. Probably my favorite cheap beer, but only for sentimental reasons.

Can to lager glass:
Pours a ridiculously pale gold with a dish soap sized/appearance of a white head.
Scent is grain, detergent, aluminum.
Plenty of carbonation, yet still feels flat....watery
Taste is primarily grain.
It is what it is...which is actually fairly drinkable, to be honest.  
There are much worse out there.....Have to give it some credit for 109 years of production.

Originally reviewed: 6/30/09. Had some boys over for some pool and darts and they brought over some tallboys of this and other suspect cheap lagers. Haven’t ever reviewed this, so why not?

Pours a very clear palest of yellows with a big frothy white head on top. Decent retention. This left some very pretty rings and sticky lacing globs all over the glass. Surprising. Smells of cheap husk, grass, and a sour off-note. 

The mouth is watery as water. Very thin and weak. Flavor is weak lemony grass and cheap grains. Nothing to this at all. Refreshing? Yes. Good? No. I’ll pass.

I’d be lying if I said I didn’t drink at least one of these a week. At $7.99 a twelve pack it is the best value for an American macro there is. I sing karaoke with my girlfriend every weekend and while we usually have a Duvel or other craft beer before we leave home, the backwoods dive bar we sing at has your "usual" beer selection. So we order a bucket of High Life and take it easy. I really dont even bother with pouring this in a glass, but the aroma from the bottle isnt too bad. A bit yeasty and bread-like. The taste is very sweet and doughy, with loads of carbonation. Unfortunately, it is a bit watery, but what do you expect? I can’t complain too terribly much about High Life. When the money is tight (like it has been for awhile now), it will always be there. The champagne of beers? Certainly not. Thirst-quencher on a hot night? Absofuckinglutely.

nice golden color for an american lager. nice head too.

smells like it says on the can, champagain of beers I got that wine champaign smell.

has a bit of a floral taste a little metalic maybe from the can. 

it was a little dry but a little more smooth than what i remembe from my binge drinking days.

overall not to bad for an amarican lager.

It was served ice cold in a frosted mug and developed about an inch and a half of head. It smelled like beer. It tasted like beer. It went down easy and usually always does.
