It is the product of a fermentation process involving yeast and hops, so I’ll eliminate all the high minded crapola say it was a pretty refreshing brewski.
It is great for what it is.  Price/quality is unmatched, pairs perfectly with lawn mowing.

Originally rated February 2005. Ahhh... the "Champagne of beers". Poured a golden colour with a nice white head and some foamy lace. Aromas of bitter malt and smell of alcohol. Carbonation was looking mighty fine, a bit like champagne. Retention of head is not bad at all. Mmm... mmm... cereal taste, which I know most critics hate, but I love this clean and refreshing taste. It is damn cheap (even cheaper then their Lite) and for summer, is refreshing as hell. O.K. maybe hell is not refreshing, but anyways. I tried this brew with a friend when we used to do our white trash selection of the week, and since then, I have been hooked on it as my affordable redneck swill drink of choice. Sorry to disappoint ! P.S. The one I buy is also brewed by Molson in Canada (very similar tasting to O.V. - same brewer) and is not pushed very well here.

Brief write up. Out of all the BMC macro lagers, this is probably my favorite. It’s not good, but I can get it down quite easy, unlike Miller Lite. Little flavor with excessive carbonation, otherwise not that horrible. Better than Miller Lite, that’s for sure.
tasted on tap and canned. refreshing and..... well, nothing else! taste like a mass produced brew
Sweet and gassy. Hops are non existant faint taste of corn. Easy to drink beer. But a pretty poor choice unless you are looking for a cheap and easy drunken binge.
24oz can. Rating #1692. Clear light yellow pour with a big bubbled white head. Clean crisp grains and a little corn sweetness. Pale lager taste, clean and not terrible. (2304)
Draught at Mikkeller Office. Clear golden - white head. Corn. Citrus. Canflewax. Light light fruity. Light light bitterness. Plain.
I wish this got more respect. I love this. It’s not good, but I love it. It’s a much sweeter beer than most and definitely lets me live the high life.
Aroma of yeast, slight poultry broth and sour.  Pours bland blond and highly carbonated.  Taste is very bready.  Hints of kaiser roll and a slight sour mash.

24oz can - pours pale yellow with quickly diminishing white head.  Nose is cardboard.  Flavor is corn, trace malts and faint hops.  taste is sweeter than I remember it being and slightly less bitter as well.  Sticky mouthfeel with watery texture.  I also recall there being a smokiness, but it is not there.  I must say the nostalgia will bump up the overall scoring.
12 oz bottle pours yellow with a white head.  Aroma mostly of grains.  Taste is the grains with a bit of yeast.
Typical mass-produced stuff with the caveat that this is a bit sweeter (I won’t say maltier) than most, which IMHO makes it more drinkable than most. You can do a lot worse in the world of bad beer.
Smell is of corn. Taste is similiar and has little hop balance.Mouthfeel is medium, fairly accurate for the style.
Draft. Pours yellow with small white head. Taste is your typical mass produced brew. Drink able.
on tap-pours pale yellow with a white head.  Aroma is grain/corn.  Taste is grain/corn, grassy/musty hops.  Light/quick finish.

24 oz can. Not sure how they came up with "the champagne of beer" tag line but it certainly missed the mark. Typical pale lager with lots of grain aroma, pale yellow colour, white foam and bland flavour.

355ml bottle pours a pale straw color with a small white head that leaves no lacing.  Aroma is cheap grains and faint hops.  Taste is light malt sweetness and a terrible hop bitterness in the finish.  Below average for the style and not recommended.

12oz bottle poured into a shaker. Pours a clear pale yellow with about a half finger of white head. Aroma of skunk, corn and wet grains. Taste is light sweet. Corn, cereal and a little metal. Medium bodied with a thin texture. Lively carbonation and a halfway decent finish. Overall, I don’t hate this beer. I would choose this any day over any "light" beer out there.

Bottle.  Lots of carbonation, faint hop aroma and flavor.  Slightly bitter finish.  Better than most domestic lagers, although that’s not saying much, as it’s a very weak field.  Would not buy with my own $.

I’ve tried dozens of imports but sometimes there’s nothing quite like an ice cold Miller High Life after cutting the grass on a hot summer day in North Carolina.  Sure, it’s not made in small batches by monks in Belgium but I’ve had many micro-brews and imports that simply don’t compare to Miller High Life.  Just because a beer is expensive doesn’t necessarily mean that it’s good.  For all you beer snobs out there, Miller High Life is exactly what it’s supposed to be, a smooth, drinkable, crisp and refreshing beer at a tasty price.  When it comes to American Pilsen style lagers, Miller High Life is the best of them.
If your drinking this your not living the high life at all. Would rather just be sober an thirsty
It’s industrial lager and if that’s what your looking for it’ll deliver everything you want and then some.
Okay beer, but I was arrested drinking this stuff, so not a big fan of it anymore. haha

Can: pours a nice clear yellow with a big fluffy off white head.  I don’t know what to say.  It’s not what I turn to when I really want to drink a beer, but it’s exactly what it’s supposed to be.  Crisp, refreshing, just beer.  Way better in a can than bottle.
Well...it’s quite drinkable..but that’s all there is to say about this beer...smooth, kind of refreshing..but bland and watery.
With a nice yellow, champagne body, this beer isn’t too bad at all. Refreshing, yet bland at the same time - what kills it for me is the metallic taste that seems to accumulate... sip after sip.
This beer is watery and very bland. That being said its cheap and effect for an afternoon or evening when you just want to drink alot of bubbly bear.

Clear as glass, pale yellow pour with a fluffy, white head.  The aroma is bland corn and slight skunk.  The body is light and thin with average carbonation, not champagne-like at all.  The taste has a very slight bitterness mixed with some metallic.
#1073 bottle; Nose is corn, piss, late weak lemon, feel is watery, carb is medium, taste is green apple, piss, corn
Oh yes...the High Life!  Review?  No, I don’t think so.  You know what this is so be quiet and drink it if you happen to find one in your possession.

Poured from bottle. This is the worst beer I have ever had. Smells of skunked corn. Looks like piss. Taste is very offensive. If your that hard up on money to buy this crap dig through the couch cushions, for a few cents more you can buy something halfway drinkable.

Poured into dimple mug from 12 oz bottle. Clear pale yellow with thin head. Tastes very lightly of corn and malt. Carbonation harsh on tongue, otherwise thin and watery. A typical American adjunct macrobrew, but definitely not the worst I’ve ever had. Made for chugging ice cold by the six-pack, not that I recommend that.
Pours clear golden. No aroma, very little taste, mostly pissy, yesty, metallic. Not completely awful out of a bottle.
MHL is a true American Classic. Smaller bubbles creates the smooth texture and clean finish. A truly enjoyable beer!

Drank straight from a clear 12oz bottle.

Appearance was typical of adjunct lagers, clear and pale yellow with a decent white head. Plenty of carbonation with this one.

What I could smell of it, corn is a big ingredient and this is quite apparent along with the cooked vegetable aroma that usually accompanies beers of this style. Still it is not off-putting.

The taste is dominated by corn with not much malt coming through. Little hop bitterness as well and no hop flavor. Carbonation is plenty, though and this leads to a nice dryness leaving you wanting another drink.

Overall, this beer is not spectacular but it is what it is. It is one of my favorite american adjunct lagers.

Went to Oktoberfest last year in Munich and I must say, the Germans do not know how to brew a good beer. After returning to the States I bought a couple of 30 packs of High Life and it was like heaven. Pours a beautiful gold with a head worthy of Gandhi himself. Slightly more carbonated than other beers, but this adds to it’s unique taste and it’s reputation as the "Champagne of Beers". It lives up to it’s nickname!
12oz bottle, during root, worst choice ever.  This beer isn’t my favorite because of the sweeter thicker palate, goes down with a sour note.  Just not what I want or will ever have again.
There’s nothing wrong with drinking some completely shit beer every once and a while, especially when it comes in a 32oz can!
I don’t know why I tried it but curiosity got the best of me. Almost killed me. Flavored water with a mild hop taste and grassy finish.

Looks like someone peed in a bottle. What else is new... Tastes like straight water with a touch of alcohol. I remembered liking it more than any other cheap american pale, but now, I don’t think I will ever buy this again. Still better than your Bud and any light version of similar beer.

I saw other reviewers mention a doughy aroma, and I’ll be damned if that’s not exactly what it smells like. Looks like your average neon-gold US beer, tastes a bit like it smells, doughy. It may not taste delicious, but at least it’s a bit different from the other ’big US’ beers which are usually sharp and tart.

recommended for beer pong, or if low on cash.

Video review at: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-hjkcHU0G1E



Appearance: Transparent straw, 2-finger head dissipates to layering, minimal lacing



Smell: Raw dough, bready malts, buttery biscuit, old tennis ball, corn straw



Taste: Thin body, raw dough, concord grape funk, corn, straw, old tennis ball, stainless steel sweetness, crisp finish, attenuated + dry, water-like mouthfeel, high carbonation



Pairings: Pizza
Drank directly from bottle at my friend’s poker night. Bright golden color with weak white head, no lace. Typical mass-produced adjunct light lager. Not good, but drinkable when ice cold.

Bottle.  Pale yellow appearance, with a small white head.  Aromas of sweet malt, with maybe a hint of skunk.  Pretty standard macro lager flavor, but actually fairly refreshing and drinkable, especially on a hot day.   [831]
This beer is sweet like coca cola. If you judge it on its own merits, it is actually decent. Better than the other macros in my opinion.

Nope, you’re not seeing things! I’m actually doing a review on a brew that I enjoyed many moons ago; Miller High Life! I must say that this brew tastes better than what I remember as I have not tried any in ages! There’s not much going on except for the ever present taste of corn but this brew is very crisp and a good thirst quencher. One thing I have noticed is that I prefer the canned beer as opposed to the bottle beer. This is due to the fact that the bottle is clear and sunlight does a big number on destroying the taste of the brew if it is not properly stored at any point between the brewery to your counter. Quite the nostalgic brew for me as it brings up some great memories from way back when!
For years this was my go to lawnmower beer, and although I enjoy a pbr sometimes, this will always be one of the best at what it does, refreshes after a long day working in the yard,
Bottle. Yellow. Sour and acrid smell- maybe a little sulfuric. Is crisp and light but very hard carbonation (like cheap champagne).
I like this beers commercials and thats about it. very bubbly and reminds me of foul water.

12oz bottle from HEB.  Pour is very clear yellow with a finger of white head that actually stuck around for a bit and laced slightly.  Very clean lager taste, with a slightly bitter end.  Some hoppiness in the middle.  Perhaps a bit of adjunct (probably corn) in there, though it’s not overpowering (I’m looking at you, Rolling Rock).  The palate is more substantial than many macros.  I’ll be damned if this isn’t a very drinkable beer.  And at $7 for 12 bottles, very affordable.  I wouldn’t brag to friends about it, but I’d offer them one.
Well, out of all the cheap, watery beers, this is my favorite. Taste better then your run of the mill ’American Lagers’

Serving glass: Poured from bottle into Pint glass.

Appearance: Very pale yellow with thin white head and surprisingly nice lacing.

Aroma: Very grainy, mildly sweet, with very light spicy hops.

Taste: Grainy sweet malts, and the corn is thankfully mostly hidden. Slightly spicy and peppery at the end.

Palate: Moderately high carbonation, light body. I wish the finish was a little drier.

Overall: Actually pretty damn good for an Adjunct Lager. Very refreshing and easy to slam down a few.

Nothing special, but if cash is tight, and you your tired of water or soda, give it a shot. I find it refreshing right after mowing the lawn. It’s re-hydrating and will start cooling you off and getting you ready for a real beer
A little more color than your standard pale lager, no aroma, a little skunky in fact. Slightly thick and dry on the palate. I’ll stick with MGD.
Clear golden blond coloured beer with lots of carbonation and a large white head. Sweet light malty hinted aroma; Medium palate. Finish is sweet, light hoppy hinted. Very short taste.

Taste is very watery with a lot of carbonation and a hint of grainy beer.  Appearance is fairly light, aroma is fairly minimal.  Three selling points are that the taste isn’t offensive, it’s fairly inexpensive (Price is less than Miller Genuine Draft or Budweiser), and the label is fairly classy so even though you’re drinking a low-end beer, you can feel like you’re drinking something with at least a hint of class and tradition.  It’s not a bad option for if you’re really low on cash, or if you get a couple for free when you’re out of beer and can’t afford to buy more (That’s basically what happened to me with my latest- under those circumstances, it’s almost like manna from heaven.).  If you have a decent amount of beer money, though, you’ll probably only want to go back to this very occasionally.
This beer is really pretty decent, but still nothing much to it.  I like some more complexity.

Well see, its friday night.  and you know ehat that means.  Narna will be home from the evening shift at the old folks home anyh minute now and i gotta be drunk just to deal the foul mouthed whore.  So i planed it all out see.  I got me a 6 pack of tall boy millers and i pounded them all down real fast like.  Im jest finishing my last one right now.  And I can tell yout this, this beer has just the right combanation of vodka and carbonation.  Yessir, these go down real smooth like with a generous amount of burping after each slamm.  I really like this golden beer, they are not lying when they say it is the champagne of beers.  Its good stuff so if you have a whore wife like narna, i sugges going out and buying yourself some of these bad boys.  it will put you in jess the right state of mind for dealing with worthless wifes.  why wont we ever move out of this hot trailer.

Horrible beer. Hard to drink to boot. Bud is better just for drink-ability. The only beer I’ve had worse than Miller is Miller after the distributor sold it to us
post SKUNK. Disgusting

Long Island, NY - 12 oz. With my shahi paneer. Pours golden clear with small amount of head, tiny bubbles with a moderate amount of lace. Aroma is slightly of malt and champagne. Taste is crisp and and ends with a a tiny bit of malty aftertaste. Lots of carbonation. Not bad to enjoy with everyday dinner and spicy food. A small commercial brew that IMO is better than other domestics.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
I had this from a can in my like and maybe once from a bottle.  One of the worst beers ever made.

Not horrible. Smells like sweet yeasty grain and corn. It’s crystal clear with a pretty decent head for a cheap lager....if drank from bottle. There Is basically no body. Light finish. Long lasting interesting aftertaste. 

9.99 for a 12 pack of bottles....almost unbeatable for cheap beer.
Hard to believe, when we were kids, that we were dumb enough to drink this terrible mockery of beer! Flavored piss water.
Hops are non existant faint taste of corn. Easy to drink beer. Poor choice unless you are looking for a cheap and easy drunken binge. nothing great
Out of all the "macros" this may be may favorite.nothing special about it,it just seems to have more overall flavor than the rest.

Had this brew at a frat party.  I now know why they had it, cheap and shitty.  This stuff really fills you up quick.  The real problem is the lingering aftertaste.  This crappy aftertaste just sticks to your tongue and doesn’t leave for 5-10 minutes no joke.  I’d rather drink Buck Range Light....
Sweet and gassy. Hops are non existant faint taste of corn. Easy to drink beer. But a pretty poor choice unless you are looking for a cheap and easy drunken binge.

Poured from a clear glass bottle, this was my attempt to "Take Back the High Life".  Pours clear and sparkling (I guess that is why they call it "The Champagne of Beer") light yellow with an average, fizzy white head, medium-long retention with good lacing.  Aroma is light corn, wet notebook paper, rice, and celery.  Flavor is wet paper (I know because I made spitballs in elementary school), rice, and light butter.  Light body and low warmth, moderate carbonation (remember, this is "The Champagne of Beer") and a dry, thin finish.

Can to pint glass. Pour is clear pale yellow with a big foamy head that slowly fades and shows continuous lacing. Aroma is dirty grass hay and malt. Taste is more the same but has a odd crisp lemon taste on the finish. Palate is thin water lots of carbonation.

Situation: Watching Celebrity Apprentice...
Glassware: Ommegang pokal...
Appearance: Sparkling, bubbling--the champagne of beers! Ragged bubbling head sports an uneven head in time...
Aroma: pungeant, sharp scents reminiscent of Saaz--and ferrous oxide...
Palate: soft, inoffensive with a wash-down-whatever consistency....
Taste: Beefy finish--a la a Slim Jim--culminates a hopless introduction and a swift, bland but crisp body...
Overall: When I think of the High Life, I think of  (in this order): Brother Jer, bad gas, and a case that costs half of what I usually spend. Still, Yuengling’s price iss comparable, and sentimentality cannot offset the fact that this beer pairs best with popcorn and Silo cups...

American beer especially mainstream macros get a bad press. I can see why. They are often sweet gassy affairs with a slighly false taste and an artificial edge. Hops are non existant and corn is the only abiding element. Miller is an example of such a beer. The nose is faint .It smacks of corn and pure carbonation. It doesnt last long on the palate. BUT this is a sweet easy to drink beer. It’s not meant to be hoppy. It’s meant to be consumed cold and in bottles ( important as MHL is poor in cans) . It’s not pretending to be a Euro lager , nor is it too strong to session. For that reason I like it. it’s sweet and pleasant to drink. I’m not going to crucify it just because it’s an easy target. I have a soft spot for Miller especially as it is becoming harder to find in Taiwan and is being slowly replaced by the Vietnamese made version that tastes of washing up liquid.

Bottle. Seemed appropriate, somehow, to start my second five hundred ratings with this. Looks like, well, beer; all the beer we’ve seen on commercials for years, that particularly lambent gold with a white head. Smells like skunk farts, though. Tastes like adjunct, cheap white grape juice, creamed corn, and despair. Finishes blah. Drinks blah. Champagne? More like Champale.
A - Fruity and yeasty A - Light yellow white thin white head T - Light sweetness P - Thin with soft carbonation O - If I was thirsty....

drank from a 24 oz can.  Been awhile since I had one, used to drink it all the time in high school.  Pretty bad, worse than I remembered, only barely passable.  FLavor is of corn adjunct with a very nasty paint thinner flavor throughout, and as it warms a little some vomit on the finish.  Gross, drinkable, but just barely.
The corn flakes of beer!  Tastes like fermented corn yet I still love it for the price.

Oh the high life! We’re back in the high life again! Can’t help but here some Steve Winwood in my head.....boy we are slummin it tonight!

Well some lovely crappy hop extracts, and cheap ingredients. Its lacking the sweet corn i expect from molson and labatt, so thats a plus. This is pretty non descript boring fizzy yellow water.

I partook in consuming about 4-5 of these not only during one of my band’s crappy shows playing in front of 9 people, but also at a good friend’s 30th birthday party with the "Queensday" theme of all orange attire.  No, this really isn’t a beer review but I don’t really care because if you came looking for an honest assessment of High Life I’d feel sorry for you.  It’s a cheap, mass produced beer that goes down cold so you don’t notice any taste, merely alcoholic water.  I guess it tastes decent, but there are tens of thousands of better beers out there.

Total nostalgia kick here, but High Life hits some long-lost basic American macro swill jones I get every once and a while. Weird toasted corn and grain notes, no hops, overcarbonated as hell, but damned if I’ll turn one down.

Bottle at Ace of Spades venue in Sacramento, CA, on April 23, 2011. Before the Amon Amarth show.
Clear pale yellow color, small white head. Sweet malty taste, I’m looking for DMS out of predjudism, but I don’t ind it. Moussy mouthfeel, low bitterness. Sweet sugary scent. Not too bad.
High rating because I’m comparing to other mass produced beers. More flavor that bud or coors etc. Won’t stand up to a craft beer competition. Tastes best in a 30 pack on the lake.

Dont let the commercials fool you this isnt really that great of a beer, its extremely dry and the aftertaste is pretty nasty dont get me wrong its better than Miller Lite but its still a horrible beer along with the whole Miller franchise.
There is really not much to speak of here.  It tastes a lot like other mass produced beer but it does have some body.  Good summer lawnmower beer.
Hard to compare it to the few I’ve tried but if this is the high end of the shitty beers this is going to be a long jagged road filled with nails, broken glass, and salty death of tastebuds.

This is my go to cheap beer. Out of all the macros this is by far my favorite and I cant say too much bad about it. Other than being mass produced and a so called "shit beer" I love it.  Not much aroma except corn and bread. Flavor is non existant but it does the job. Thanks Miller for doing something right!
Grainy malts/sweetness and slightly tart throughout.  As far as the biggest macros go, this is among the best.

Miller High Life, the "champagne of beers," dates to 1903. Miller High Life is a classic American-style lager recognized for its consistently crisp, smooth taste and iconic clear-glass bottle. Miller High Life embraces its rich heritage and is known by its drinkers as an authentic, unpretentious beer. As the best beer value in America, we encourage beer drinkers to "Take Back the High Life."

Personally I enjoy a good high life.  If I am going to buy a low priced beer in a largeish quantity I plan on sharing with friends at a party of another social gathering, this is never one that I hear complaining about. It is one of the better  light beers that comes in cans.  the bottles are always preferable in my opinion.

Im a huge fan of the fact that the photo of this beer is of a 40... Clear yellow standard yellow macro, with a sizeable head... corn, light sweet, mild grass.... stingingly lively, macro abrasive sweet corn not crazy offensive.. light body...

Grain, cereal, corn -- a macro in every sense.  Better than some.  All the malt you can handle, and the hop presence granted by a suspicion that someone once walked through the corner of the warehouse with an Arrogant Bastard Ale in their lunchbox.  Over the top fizzy mouthfeel.  I’d much rather have a Landshark if I’m going to go to this kind of beer...
The champaigne of beers is more like the Ripple of beer. Not watery, but tasteless, like seltzer water, with little color and aroma. Buy local.

12oz bottle.  I am on a tight budget to save for my Key West vacation.  I can get 18 of these for $10.99!  This American Macro might be my new favorite.  PBR was my go-to cheap beer, but this tastes lighter and a little bit sweeter.  The flavors are corn, sugar, and just a tiny little hint of metallic bitter hops.  I can totally drink 5 of these on the beach and be in beer-buzz heaven.  I’ll be back to craft beer after vacation.

the 40 oz. picture is amusing..to it appropriateness.  At first glance it says "i’m golden and tasty and somehow related to champagne!" liar.  Pour:  pale gold, white fizzy head non-lasting.  Aroma:  Corn, fuel.  Taste:  Corn, fuel.

Bottled. A light yellow beer with a white head. The aroma has notes of brewing cereal and malt. The flavor is sweet with notes of honey and malt as well as a lighter skunky note of brewing cereal. Thanks yespr for sharing.
12 fl oz clear bottle. Pours clear and golden yellow with a small white head. Aroma is grassy to slight cornish. Sweet cornish, grassy and dry hayish. Bitter and cornish finish.
This one is primarily found in cans. It isn’t the worst macro but it is for sure on the lowest rung. It is a corny, mineral watery mess.
One of the worst tasting beers of all time. If ur drinking this u need to step up ur beer game.

Color = a brilliant gold. Aroma = cereal grains. Taste = barley and hops. I’ve always enjoyed the High Life. It’s like a macro but with a some funk that makes it better. More taste than a macro. Easy drinking and refreshing. As far as Macro lagers go, this has to be one of the best.
I do not think they should be able to call this the champagne of beers.  Its just not right.  watery and awful.
Bottle pours gold with a white head.  Smells as though it was brewed in a tin can.  I’m glad mine wasn’t a 40oz.
Blind tasting - Least favorite from the tasting.  Strong scent of egg, very unpleasant.  Would be perfectly happy if I never come across this beer again.
Ah, who doesn’t want to live the so called high life? This highly carbonated brew is everything you would expect for a macro brew, grain, corn water.

A: Slightly golden with an okay white head and some carbonation.

S: Some hints of grain in addition to the smell of adjuncts.

T: Not at all good. Almost tastes like fake beer with metal in it. 

M: Too much carbonation and a weird metallic vibe to it. Feels and tastes like I bit my tongue.

D: Same as the mouthfeel. Absolutely stay away from this one. As far as I’m concerned, the worst of the macros.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 05-02-2009

A rugby mate gave me a can of this after practise.  Surprisingly, it didn’t taste like skunk, urine, or skunk urine.  If anything, it tasted almost like nothing.  Slightly malty with a touch of caramel, but mostly funky water.  Cant nail down the aroma or appearance, since it was canned.  Not the worst beer ever, but loses points for calling itself the champagne of beers.

Tasted in a 12 oz bottle at the Black Sheep in Colorado Springs, CO.  Incredibly light, translucent Pale Lager appearance.  Skunky Pale Lage aroma.  Very light body with not much flavor other than bitterness and skunkiness.

From a 12oz bottle, no need for a glass here I believe. Aroma from bottle malty and stale possible moldy bread. Taste is light and watery, corn, malts, stale vomit aftertaste like I was drink a decent beer and woke up with this taste in my mouth. You’d have to be living a "High Life" to really enjoy this. That being said, I do enjoy one after I’m so piss drunk all I can drink is something I can taste anyway. Certainly not the worst Macro Pale Lager.

I would rate this below Bud and Pabst but above all other piss beers.  Aroma is really bad, best to drink out of the bottle to keep aroma down.  I wonder if corn beer is bad for you like HF corn syrup..?

I find this an every day or any time beer. It’s not bitter and leaves very little unpleasant after taste. Good with meals or for game day. Better than Bud or Coors in my opinion for everyday mass consumption beer. This is my go to beer because I know what to expect and it tastes great all the time.
Certainly better than Bud or Coors.  But that ain’t saying much.  At least High Life is yellow and not clear.  Way too corn based.  So much sugar.  Beyond that nothing.

Pours a pure white, three-finger head that fades slowly to a thin layer and leaving some lace. Light-medium carbonation and light bodied. Crystal clear pale straw color. Nose is ?? Flavor is sweet corn with faint hints of hops in background. Squeaky clean finish. Good lawn mower beer. Better than MGD. The champagne of beers, who are they kidding? $1.25 for a 12oz bottle from Colonial Spirits, Acton, MA.
Out of all the light beers. High life is my LEAST least liked beer. The only way it is halfway decent is with it so cold there is ice chips
right out of the can.  Tastes skunky, with flavors of corn and old straw and hay.
Golden color. Tastes like cheap beer, corn showing up and nothing special about it. Good for the price. More like Sparkling Wine of Beers.
This beer is awful weak. Very little flavor, hardly any aroma. High Life? I’d hae to say Miller Low Life. They can do better than this. might as well drink water.
not better than mgd or coors  but better than bud if your gonna buy a cheap good dumbestic brew buy this or amber bock or malt liqour for taste buy a stout

A: poured into a snifter. pours a perfectly clear yellow, which looks like urine after a multivitamin. Nice white head on top, about two finger widths, with a low retention rate. fair lacing at best.

S: smells like corn pops. like unsweetened corn pops. some hints of watered down veggies.

T: slight sweetness in this. I am getting a ton of corn in this, which is odd considering the fact that I was expecting to just type that it tastes like high life. As it warms it gets so much worse...like stale tortilla chips.

M: high carbonation level for a macro. mouthfeel is watery.

D: could I pound these? Yes! Will I? No. not bad for the pool area, though.

Lucent yellow, thin white head, thin watery body, high carbonation.



Aroma: musty grain, a bit of funk.



Taste: watery, grain, oxidation, some adjuncty funk, a hint of wild or artificial grape flavoring.



At least it’s not sweet.

Oh geez, if this is the champagne of beers, I’m pretty sure someone peed in mine.  Horrible, if you want a headache, drink some, if you want taste pick up something that doesn’t taste like a sweet, watered down version of moose pee with some water and hops with it.  Gross.

Pours a pale yellow with a white head.The wasn’t able to get much of an aroma but I was able to sence was a light wheat sent.The flavor was a bland sweet and metallic taste.It went down smooth but had no aftertaste.Overall not as bad as other pale lagers but their was nothing to it at all.
Just your regular old run of the mill beer... nothing special. Just something to drink

The champagne of beers really lives up to its expectation…not really.  Fizzy orange pour with white head, aroma of corn, some sweaty socks (not funk, just nasty sweat), and some hay.  Taste is sweat, grain, chemical, and corn with a slightly bitter finish.  Higher overall score because it was my college beer.

When I’m looking to wash down chicken wings or give away a free beer to someone I don’t like very much, but might have a minor obligation to....Yeah NATE I’m talking about you.... I go for the High Life.
for being out of work force to buy cheap beer before a dodger game.. lol you get what you pay for best when ice cold

Pours pale yellow with foamy head. Head looks fake. Aroma is very light, mostly corn. Taste is a very light corn/cereal flavor. A slight lingering off flavor. Very thin. Mostly innocuous...neither good or bad. Save for a day  of yard work. There are cheaper beers that are just as good or better (such as Genesee).

Bottle:  The aroma is lightly sweet with hints of soap and faint grass.  It pours a transparent light gold with a half inch white head that fades a soapy film after a minute or so.  The flavor starts with lightly sweet with some faint cereal/grain notes.  The finish has some light grass and straw notes.  Light bodied with mild carbonation with a somewhat thin and watery mouthfeel.  Rather watery and bland flavor, but the lightly soapy aroma is a little offensive.
Smells and tastes terrible. It’s definitely cheap, but wouldn’t be my choice.

West USA trip 2010. Bottle. This one of the very few cheap ass beers I bought on my trip. And offcourse, I shouldn’t have. Nothing high about it. Offcourse it won’t get me down either. Anyway. Aroma is grainy. Pale yellow coloured beer with a white head. The taste is also a bit grainy and very watery. Nothing there. No taste. And so, yes it is smooth, they’re absolutely right! But that’s only qualified as art if you actually add taste to the beer.
Pours a pale medium yellow, nose is chalky, taste is way too heavy of soap.
I drank this stuff regularly before Coors bought Miller.  It was cheaper before they started marketing it to the masses again.  Slightly sweeter than most yard beers.
12oz bottle at Fricker’s in Dayton, OH.  I got a bottle of this cause it’s about all they had...and it was only $1.50!   Other then that it was bad.
#4 in my "I’m unemployed so I have to buy cheap beer" series.  Thin, yellow, thin white head that dissipates quickly.  Smooth, malty taste.  Not too bad for a cheapie.
Can. Medium head with medium duration. Color is pale golden. Aroma and taste are malt, hops and soap. Semi bitter finish.
Can at American-can tasting Sdr. Borup. Frothy white good mostly lasting head. Yellow colour. Light malty and hoppy aroma. Light bitter flavor. Short light bitter finish. Very watery palate.
Can. Clear pale yellow with small white head. Flavour is malt, sweet and watery.
Back in the day when I was cheap and young I loved this stuff.  Now that I am older and my palate has matured...not so much.
(32oz can thanks to zdk9) pale yellow, very little bubbles. Nose of chlorine, corn, alcohol and cereal grains. Taste of watery grain, light on everything and mildly offensive.
Actually not too bad when measured against its competitors and/or relatives. Enought taste that I’ll take it over most super macros
At least it’s not; coors, bud, coors light,bud light, keystone etc.... What I am trying to say is that it’s better than the worst.

Appearance: Pours a light gold color with a 1 finger head which dissipates quickly; very minimal lacing.

Smell: Hints of corn and other grains. Not a lot going on.

Taste: Slightly bready up front with notes of malt. Corn and grain throughout with a slight metallic hint as well.

Mouthfeel: Light bodied, almost like a light beer. Fairly strong carbonation.

Drinkability: Very high drinkability. You can easily knock several of these back without thinking about it.

Overall: Obviously it’s not a high end beer but I’ll take it every time over other Bud/Coors/Miller options. You definitely can’t beat the price. You can get a 12 pack of bottles here in NC for $6.79. This and PBR are my go to when I want something cheap.

Ah, the champagne of beers. Pours a clear light yellow with a foamy head that leaves some lacing. There is a mellow yeast ester , but corn makes up the majority of the aroma. The flavor is pretty sweet all the way through, has mostly a corn flavor, and finishes semi crisp. Not bad but would not say it’s great.
Drank from a 12 oz. bottle.  Nice and clear amber-yellow which left some foam.  Aroma of malts and the taste matched it.  Lightlly hopped with a decent mouthfeel.  Overall, a decent macro-brew.
cheap gold look, mildly citrusy aroma and taste, light but with just enough flavor to be refreshingly enjoyable
Oops... I just spilled it all over the computer desk.  At least it wasn’t very good beer.
I’ll give this one a 5 for appearance, but other than that I liked nothing at all about this beer. If this is living the High Life, I’ll take my chances elsewhere.
(32oz can, from zdk9)  Pours a clear pale yellow body with a small white head.  Aroma of corn, metallic, and chlorine (swimming pool).  Flavor of cereal, corn, and chlorine with a watery mouthfeel.
Can I saw zdk09 bring to the table, clear golden color with skunky butter aromas, sweet corn flavors

This beer is terrible.  I like the occasional PBR but I have always hated high life.  It is not even good for cooking brats.  Aroma is nonexsistent.  Head is about an inch.  Taste is akin to a glass of perrier mixed with poison.  Palate is far too dry.  Bad, bad, Bad!

Not sure who provided this 32 ounce can, but thanks to whoever it was.

The beer pours a clear yellow color with a white head. The aroma is chlorinated corn. Absolutely awful. The flavor is corn with some grassy notes. Luckily, the chlorine from the aroma is not that apparent in the flavor. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation.
(24oz can) Smells like a pool with metal sides that a sweaty soccer player just took a dip into. Tastes...slightly better than that. Only slightly.
Well, not as bad as I thought.  Not the best cheap beer but not totally offensive. Serving: Tap and Bottle
Pours a yellow color with corn smell and taste.  I couldn’t believe I had not rated this one, so I bought some and realized it isn’t worth the dollar I spent.  Never again!!

12 oz. bottle.  Pours light gold with thin head.  Not much aroma, just some faint malt.  Not much going on with taste.  Not offensive, just not very much there.  Guess on a hot day it would be drinkable.
"The Champage of Beers" indeed, its about the same color.  Really quite tasteless and watery.
Oh man this stuff sucks. But i do have fond memories of camping with friends on spring break in high school with a cooler full of it.    Good times

Ladon, one of the local bands I play for in Eugene consumes about 20 cases of this stuff per year. I don’t know why but it’s just what everyone buys. This is a decent lager, though it can only be found in 12oz, 16oz, and 32oz variants around here. This is about as refreshing as sparkling water and packs a tiny buzzy. It’s decent, but I would never call this the champagne of anything. Maybe the RC Cola of cheap lagers but this is nothing special. Better than many, yet worse off than most. It is very drinkable and not offensive to even the most sensitive snobby beer geeks.

Pours like magnificent golden cat piss.  Stinks of funky lager.  Burns the palate.  Best drank at about 32 degrees.  As it warms, the funky cat piss really shows up for the party.  Better than Strohs, though.
12 oz bottle.  Aroma of an American pale lager, but not as light on the palate as most.  One of the better cheap beers.

The smell reminds me of lake water.  Lake water may look more appealing in a glass however.  It pours with  a decent head, but has very little color.  The fact that the tiny bubbles do look like champaigne is probably the most interesting thing about this beer.  The flavor is traditional American lager, somewhat lighter than Budweiser.

Nothing special or outstanding about it, and considering its category as cheap american pale, being not outstanding is probably a good thing. For 3.50$ a 6-pack in western Alabama, its not a bad beer. On tap, its actually quite bearable. And at 58 cents a bottle, why not?

Typical American pale lager macro so I’ll pass on the usual routine. I will admit that Miller High Life has a less offensive taste than most American macros- no skunk- and even has a decent maltiness. Not exactly "real" beer but probably my favorite from the swill pile, for what it’s worth.
What is there to say? It’s the "Champagne of beers." That means it’s good, right? Oh, wait, it’s just a silly marketing ploy. Nevermind. This is a drain pour. Rated 11/22/2000

A great after-work forty ounce of "unleaded beer" it’s not anything special, but is quiet tolerable. The price here in Southern IL is $1.99 for a 40oz bottle.
Fantastic for a filler beer, makes beer pong easy on the pocketbook yet agreeable to the tastebuds. Killer for the price, but still just a mass produced beer.
This is a clear yellow with virtually no head. It has a corny, oily aroma. The taste is of oily corn with lots of fusel oils. It has a thin, bubbly mouthfeel. Below average even for a macro lager...

Miller High Life--The Champagne of Beers--Clear Bottle--2007 12 oz. Bottle.  4.70% ABV--15 IBU’s.?  (3.5 / 5.0)  6-Pack $4.99.  Thin foamy lacy white head.  Clear thin bright yellow white color.  Mild adjunct hop no stank front.  Mellow thin refreshing tangy creamy hint crisp mild caramel adjunct Pale Lager body.  Quenching hop hint mild citrus tang balanced easy smooth end.  Sampled 2/6/2008.

Miller High Life. The Champagne of beers.
ok.
Not bad appearance. Light golden color with lots of bubbles (which is I guess what you would expeact for the champagne of beers)
smell and taste are eh. nothing special or exciting. nothing really to offer.
Mouthfeel is really carbonated (duh)

O- I would pick MGD over miller high life but this isn’t bad.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 04-18-2007 03:01:43
This macro lager is a small step above its ultra-light counterparts while remaining throughly disgusting. I would never drink one unless I was planning on drinking twelve.

The High Life, unfortunately, is about as low as it gets when it comes to drinking beer. Best enjoyed at the end of your night, when you can’t really taste it anyways. Put it in a clear plastic cup, and you might even fool yourself into enjoying it.

Can.

A - Light golden color with a good sized white foamy head that disappears fast and leaves a little lacing.

S - Light and clean with the smell being grain/corn sweetness that usually accompanies Macro lagers.

T - Pretty typical Macro lager taste. Fairly sweet grain and corn. A bit of hop grassy and bitterness.

M - Light body and good amount of carbonation. Crisp.

D - Made to be easy to drink and non-offensive. Goes down easy and pretty refreshing. Taste isn’t great, but good for what it is.

Notes: Not bad for what it is suppose to be. Not too different from other Macros. Probably as good or better than most macros.

12 oz. bottle. Clear golden-yellow with a creamy, lasting half-inch of foam. Aroma is lemongrass, honey and husky grain. Flavor is a similar mix.  Creamy body is light, well balanced, and creamy but tingly.
Certainly not a high quality beer by anyones standards. But its a family favorite and i dont mind it so much. It certainly beats busch and milwakees best. Its cheap, and its not all that bad
(12 ounce bottle - pint glass)  Pours a light golden color with no head.  Slightly offensive corn malt aroma.  Taste is the same.  Same finish and soft carbonation.  Not good.

Pretty disgusting taste. Very much like skunk and corn mixed. Beautiful pour though with a crystal clear golden yellow and a medium sized bright white head. Would not recommend this beer to people who actually like beer.

Golden yellow with a white bubbly head.  Typical light beer aroma.  Metallic, slightly bitter with a faint hop character.  Watery body, some light toasty malt and a tiny bit of hops.  Light, watery, tastes better out of the can than in a glass.
The champagne of beers!  Has a mild carbonated flavor with a grainy finish.  A college favorite.

Like Miller Lite plus. A bitter, pale gold brew found at most bars/grocers. The taste is bitter and hoppy, with a non-existent scent. Not a bad way to go, but there are better drinks that you can get at the store/bar.

12 oz Bottle. Pours a light golden yellow, with substantial head and carbonation. Very slight malt and hop aromas. Slightly sweet malty taste, with some balance apparent from hops. I am a bit nostalgic towards high life, as it was my very first beer, probably affected my rating a bit. For a commerical brew, it is not offensive.

Too much variation from the different times I’ve had this, maybe it’s the clear bottle but sometimes it’s skunked and sometimes it’s not. In either case it still is a macro beer and mades for the masses. Not going into length as to why this beer sucks.

pours like champagne pale gold with a thick white head and non stop carbonation. Sickly like lacing. Aroma is sugar and corn and kind of skunked. Taste is light bitter with nothing really to note kind of like slat water.
It just leaves a disgusting taste in your mouth. the palate is biting carbonation. and Awful American pale lager.(but aren’t they all)

A: High Life pours a perfectly clear, light golden color. There are plenty of tiny bubbles and a very fluffy white head. Which I always expect from the champagne of beers.

S: I usually don’t expect too much when having an adjunct lager, and most of the time don’t really even want to smell it. This beer has a very metallic smell along with some corn. It’s not good, but it’s not as bad as many.

T: Like the nose, there is a metallic character to this beer, at least initially. After that passes, there is a mix of actual grain/malt and corn. It again makes for a sensation that is not wonderful but not terrible either.

M: Probably my favorite part about High Life is the very effervescent feel of it on the tongue.

D: It’s drinkable in the sense that AB advertises Bud Light to be: it’s basically water. The flavors are very watered down, but that’s what I expected.

Of all the commercially available American Lagers, Miller High Life is one of only two that I think truly represent the style and are worth drinking (PBR being the other). This beer pours golden with a rich white head. It is smooth and does not lack the character of most. Would I rather drink a micro IPA? Of course, but once in a while this hits the spot.
Just getting caught up on my old samples. And here we have a loser....pass....move along this is not the beer your looking for....

Bottle. Of all the basic level beers found in any grocery store, this is one of the ones I like. Its not on the top of my list, and its not something I consider great, but it has flavor compared to Miller Lite or MGD. Its simple in its corn and malt aroma and flavor, but its great ice cold and goes down easy. I can’t ask for more during hockey or baseball season.

Pours clear straw yellow with a minimal head, reducing to nothing. The nose is primarily of corn and some weird metallic note.  The flavors are reduced versions of the aroma, with a corny hop finish.... subtle but present.  The mouthfeel is thin with plenty of active carbonation.  Boring and plain, but not the worst brew out there.

Pours a nice clear yellow. Small head that fades fast. A light aroma of sweet corm malt. Taste of metallic and light hop. Slightly bitter finish. Save your money for good beer and just drin tap water. It would  be more refreshing.

12oz can.  Filtered watery yellow with a fluffy, foamy head.  Dirty malt aroma, ouch.  Somewhat creamy the first few sips because of the head, this isn’t quite as bad as I remember the 40oz version to have been.  Sweet and sugary, pretty bland really.  Not overly offensive, I’ve certainly had worse beers...from Russia.  "Always smooth, never bitter"..true enough, only the most minimal high fructose corn syrup hop flavor.  I personally find the name particularly offensive to the lower classes that generally consume the product.  Fuck Miller.

12 oz bottle to mug.  How many hundreds of these did I drink in ’pony" form in college? Pours golden yellow with thin white head.  Some skunk and hay, but very light.  Taste is light and sweet.  Thin in the mouth, but decent carbonation boosts it a little.  Finish is non-existent.  Better than many U.S. macros, but overall pretty boring.  As a friend often says, "At least you can see what you’re drinking."

I used to scof at the name "Champagne of Beers" until I gave this one an objective tasting.  It’s flavor and mouthfeel are rather reminicent of extremely cheap champage.  The aroma is turned apple cider and burnt rice.  The taste has a serious rice burn and lots of skunkyness but retains the spoiled fruit qualities that are present in the aroma.  Finish is unpleasant but brief.  Actually not the worst thing to drink if you’re focus lies elsewhere.

Nothing really special about this one.
 At all.
 There are some metallic notes besides the corn taste. Very inexpensive, and very refreshing IF very cold. Smooth cool finish. Thirsty? Give it a shot.

I have had this on tap and in bottle, it rates the same.  Pours a pale yellow with very little head.  The taste is smooth and clean, but has very little taste.  What taste is does have is ok, except a little watery and a little corny.  Attention poor college students: usually cheap, very poundable, and in general a nice session beer.

Rating #420.  Bottle available at the finer gas stations in Tampa.  Poured a light, clear yellow with a large, white, foamy head.  Nose is very malty with light hop notes.  Thin body with with a watery mouth feel.  Flavor is light malt with notes of hay and soap.  Finishes cold.

12 oz can pours piss yellow with abundant white head into a lager glass.  Typical sweet metallic corn smell.  Similar taste with a bit of breadiness.  Slippery and fizzy mouthfeel with high carbonation and low body.  Drinkable and not as terrible as some APLs.
This was the standard elephant piss we used to drink back in college.  Just an ordinary beer.

12 oz can. Straw color, white fuzzy head. Some body to it.

I agree that it lacks the foul sweetness that is so rampant in most  American macros.

Umm... how the heck have I not rated this yet?  The beer is a pissy yellow color with a thin white head.  Whether from bottles or tap, the beer is pretty consistent (unless the tap lines are full of bugs).  Medium light bodied.  Crisp and refreshing.  Flavors and aromas of light corn and simple malts/hops.  Honestly, it’s not that bad of a beer.

40oz bottle. Pours a super pale, almost off-white yellow color. Too much carbonation. What little taste there is is corn and metal. The smell is about the same. Not a fantastic beer, but if you’re looking to get drunk it does the job.

Pale pour with an offwhite head.  Aroma is metallic and Light Grain.  Flavor is much the same with some mild grassy notes.  The most enjoyable of a night of macro gulping because it lacks the foul sweetness that is so rampant in most macros.

As I sit here today, I don’t have much use for a beer like this.  Having said that, I’ll always have fond memories of this lawnmower beer.  Heck, at least it has a distinctive taste, unlike some of its’ counterparts.

24 oz can, pours pale yellow with a medium white head.  Aroma is all rice and corn.  Thin watered down corn and pale malt.  Little to no aftertaste.  I’m reminded of why I waited so long to rate this.

beer smells like buttery corn.  tastes like buttery corn.  not too heavy i guess.  maybe won’t get you drunk but will throw a cool nap at you.  Don’t really mind it.. the aftertaste is weird how it is almost magically erased.  The small sweet on the finish right before the non-aftertaste is okay enough.  I would rather drink bud, but I might buy this when i’m strapped for cash.  actually a better buy than most cheap beers especially the ones at trader joes.  been around a long time for a reason i suppose.  straight up corn water and feremented long enough to let the heavy wear off but really just a sleepy beer.  I need a bud.

Can.  Pours golden yellow with a medium white head.  Aroma and flavor are both very grainy, however this beer has more flavor than most macro lagers.  I used to drink this stuff all the time in college and it was very drinkable after 2-3 beers.  Now that I drink better beer this stuff is hard to stomach.

Pretty typical American macro. Pours pale yellow with a thin white head. A metallic aroma with a hint of grass, tastes about the same. By no means an impressive brew, but I much prefer it over Bud Lite or Miller Lite.

Miller is like the other big breweries flagship beers. Bland, plain, not much in the beer. Great advertising, but you can’t drink advertising.

Pours a clear light gold, about 1 finger of foam which has some staying power.

Smell, bland some corn some hops but only if I really try to find them.

Taste - bland boring, nothing much here, something of an unpleasant aftertaste.

Mouthfeel - very thin

Drinkability - if your going out to have a few, you can drink these without getting in too much trouble.

Contrary to popular belief, I think this beer is even worse than stuff like keystone light or busch light. smells like piss, tastes like piss, the upside is that it can be consumed for quantity. It almost made me puke with out one sip.

Thin and watery just as you would expect. No aroma to note and no real substance in the palate. Not much flavor. However, this beer is my guilty pleasure. I enjoy ths beer outside in front of a BBQ pit on a hot day. Its quantity over quality here.

341 mL Bottle. Straw body with a short lived bubbly-rocky head. Aroma of rice, cereals, Love Canal dirt, and derrière de skunk. Flavor is Eau de Lake Ontario with corn, rice, and cereals; corn flakes and derrière de skunk in the aftertaste and a chemical grassiness in the finish. This Champagne of Swills ought to be called Swiller Low Life.

Bottle. 12 oz. To be honest, I pounded this guy in about two minutes because I was late for a Dinosaur Jr. concert and someone bought a round for the entire bar. Tasted exactly what you would expect it to tast like. Not too bad, if I remember correctly.
Filtered sewer water would taste better.  I’d lick the dew of a frosty turd before I drank anymore of this.  DQI

Miller High Life 7 oz , anyone who can’t enjoy one on a hot summer day is out of there mind. 

Credit to my man Jay for  getting me back on the High Life.
Yellow.  Has a chemical quality to the taste.  Weak and ungratifying, not the finest in American beers.
typical cheap beer. pours a light yellow with a medium white head. Nothing wonderful here.

Screw all that expensive beer. I’ll leave that to you hoighty toighty people with big hats. This is the perfect beer, that is, if you enjoy drinking carbonated skunk piss. This is a golden fizzy over-carbonated joke. Those commercials are misleading and play to the average stupid american who enjoys a macro-lager. Mmmm delicious. Honestly, this beer sucks, no point in describing it any further.

Nice clear bottle, which attributes to a nice skunky taste, purely used for advertisement of it’s golden color. Aroma is slightly skunky balanced with a sweet maltiness. Lacing and a medium body is there.  Not going to break down it’s taste as it is too generic.  On the plus if you drink about $500 worth of it you can get a delivery man’s shirt for free with their rewards points program!
I like this beer, it’s got a decent flavor, and i seem to be able to drink it all night without getting heavilly intoxicated. Very pale, with very thin head.

Golden yellow color and fizzy just as the slogan denounces. Champagne of beers baby. Maybe the flavor of a cheap Brut or something. Crisp and light, not offensive and easy to drink but a bit over carbonated for me.
Classic beer.  Marketing campaign makes me want to drink it.  Light and refreshing and good flavor with no after taste.
I learned to love this while playing bar gigs.  The band got dollar pitchers of High Life.  Sure it’s terrible, but a pitcher for a dollar is too good to pass up for a five hour gig.
light and sweet. Cheap and awesome. I’ll take this over a budweiser anyday. The campaign of beer. of course... $4.50 for an 8 pack of niblets ok!

This beer is a cheap, poor-man’s beer, which is what makes it great. A 40 ounce bottle of Miller High Life literally costs no more than a 2 liter of soda pop. It has a sweet a crispy taste to it, so although it won’t win any awards, it is easy to drink.
Typical pale lager appearence, not much on the nose and tastes heavily of grain.  Better than a lot of cheap stuff but not great.

Pours palest gold with a fluffy white head, leaves a respectable lacing. Aroma of bubblegum and creamed corn. Flavor mainly a bit of bubblegum sweetness and apple peel with a hint of citrus, moving towards the off elements, definitely some cream corn and especially at the beginning, some stale cardboard. But on the whole better than mediocre. Light body, somewhat dry, decidedly refeshing. Fails to suck.
Pale yellow pour with a grassy aroma. Flavor is light and full of adjuncts.

bottle poured a light yellow in color with a thin white head. aroma has corn, grain, light hops and sweetness. flavor is mostly corn and grains, fairly sweet, and some hops at a stretch. I had a room mate years ago named miller and this was his thing, had to throw one back to old times.
My dad’s favorite beer before he switched to High Life Light... really not a bad beer, but not much better than any other Miller product.

When you look at the can, you think that you’re going to be in for something special.  Oversized can, gold colored label, looks pretty dope.  Well, that’s about where it ends.  Someone told me that High Life is just the nasty remnants of all the other Miller beers, and I wouldn’t be surprised.

Okay, for my 100th rating I chose the beer of which I had many, many "ponies" at the drive-in the night I lost my virginity - so here’s to Miller High Life and Nostalgia!  Rating based on "Pale Lager" category.

Pours a light, clear golden with moderate white head. Letting the beer breath and warm in the lager pint glass.  Head dininishes to thin but foamy layer with moderate lacing.

Aroma of grass, grains, mostly corn.  Pull date of Sept 28 on 32 oz can - they did not have ponies :(  Slightly sweet taste with hint of light malt.  Little or no hop presence.  Drinking at probably 40-45 degrees, bringing out any flavor it has.  Light to medium body with fairly pleasant taste, not skunky thank you!

Finish is slightly sweet with decent amount of bitterness.  I will enjoy the rest of the can and hopefully watch my Cardinals kick some Dodger butt - CHEERS to life!
Another bland lager. Clear bottle shows that they care more about marketing than beer quality.
Not as nasty as a lot of cheap beer, but ok beer when you are short of money
Pretty awful beer.  Good for drinking games but that’s about it.  No interesting notes

Oh yeah. Forty. Pours an absolutely crystal clear pale golden color with a large frothy head. Poor head retention and lacing. Thankfully no skunk despite the clear bottle. Aroma of grass, dirty grains and corn. Taste is corn and a big grassy finish Some faint malty notes, but mostly just corn. Watery. Thin.

Poured from a can into a pint glass

The appearance is a pale yellow with a small white head, surprisingly there was some nice lacing.

The smell is not very strong. Hints of corn, some hops and malt.

The taste is of a grain flavor, hints of corn, Not very strong hop flavor. Is sweet with a hint of malt.

The type of beer that your dad might drink on the weekends. Not heavy and is really a beer for those times that your short in cash.

If I could give this a 0 I would, holy crap this beer sucks.

I bought a case of this stuff on sale and wasn’t expecting much from the price but that’s a mistake I’ll never make again.

Bottom line, spend a couple bucks more and get something decent.

355 mL can. Pours light gold with extreme clarity. Head is weak and disappears entirely after two or three sips. Strong aroma of urine and hay with subtle corn and malt undertones.  Light body with a thin texture, a somewhat fizzy carbonation that quickly goes soft (almost flat) when poured. The finish is is weak, bitter, and mostly grassy in flavor.  A terrible beer but drinkable nonetheless.  Great for poker games and beer pong.

This is a fav from days gone bye. I still like to buy some and drimk it. Score is probably influenced by fond old memories. Yellow pour with a white head. Corn aroma, some thin malt. Taste is the same. Keep it iced to mask the adjuncts.Still, my goto beer for mass produced swill.

355 mL. Pours a light yellow with a thin, one-finger, white head that dissolves to nothing. Aroma of corn, Special K, skunky malt. Taste is fairly alcoholic as it warms sort of like cheap, boxed, carbonated white wine (literally like a champagne of beers). Sort of gives an instant headache from its terribleness. Surprisingly bad after having a night of Yuengling and Bud Light. It sort of goes out of the way to show how piss poor beer can really be.
had to give this a rating, this was my high school drink! especially being so broke this was the most you could get for $1.75... brings back memories!

Better (a bit) than Budweiser but costs more (usually). A dependable swill that you can drink a lot of.  Used to love this stuff when I was younger - prior to the discovery of "real" beer.  Still glad to drink one if nothing better is available.

12 oz can.  Smells and tastes like an American macro lager.  Indistinguishable from the majority of these insipid mass-appeal beers.  The only good thing these beers are good for in my opinion is getting drunk in social settings, like camping, partying, poker games, etc. Holy crap I sound like a snob...

What can be said that hasn’t been said about this beer. I was raised on this stuff. My old man always had a sixer of this in the fridge as far back as I can remember. So naturally this was the first beer I ever tasted. It will always hold a place in my heart. 

I’ve had this beer everyway it can be served but for this review I’m pouring it from a bottle.

In a pint glass this beer looks rather inviting. Nice golden color with a thick head that last for decent amount of time. 

The smell is midly sweet with hints of malt and corn.

Taste is crisp. Nice bite. 

I enjoy this beer. I’m not sure if it’s the nostalgia that makes me like it or if it’s just a decent macro. Probably a bit of both.

taste of fizzy water. This has more fizz than most American pale lagers- not sure if that’s a good thing, but it did raise my palate score by one. Aside from that, I was at flip cup party and the stouts I brought disappeared in under five minutes, leaving me to rate this.
I’m not quite sure how to comment on this one. Ok, it’s easy, this is an American macro pale lager. You’ve all tasted it before. So I’ll leave with: HIGH LIFE!
drinking this after a divorce will make you feel better...thanx MillerCoors we love you, keep um comin...
12 oz. bottle at Nick’s Pub in St. Louis (on special, of course).  Light gold, overbearing white head, overly carbonated, slightly skunky, bad aftertaste.

Overall Impression: 
Another one of the crappy beers from our good friends at Miller, not so terrible for the price I guess.
This is another cheap american beer that should just go away.  Hey at least they have a funny ass commercial.

Case of 32oz’ers shared amongst three great friends. My High Life buddy and I being the most important. Refreshing, bubblier than any other beer I know. This is a great beer for camping or those guys nights you just want to pound giant bottles of beer.
Drank this stuff for a while when I had no knowledge of beer and wanted something cheap.  Pale golden, white head.  Taste is slighlty malty but there is really not that much as far as flavor goes.

Canned.  Poured healthy, bright golden with a rather nice synthetic cap of white head.  The aroma picked up a pinch of lemon zest and grassy notes over pale malts and some honey.. dry cardboard-ish notes on the back of the nose.  The flavor had dry pale malts at the core, accented by crisp lemon and grassy bitterness.. grainy, especially on the back-end.  Light-bodied and watery at times on the palate.. overall, crisp and refreshing, though.. supremely non-offensive.

Poured from 16oz. Can into Pint glass.

Pours a pale straw golden yellow with a large fizzy white head that quickly dissolves and leaves no trace of existence. The nose is filled with grain and some earthy hops although the nose overall is pretty faint, I would say that is mostly grain. Flavor is almost identical to the aroma with a gentle bitterness. Its light bodied and is very carbonated. This and PBR are my two beers of choice if I’m at a complete dive bar or if I’m going to camping or such.

Nothing more glorious than drinking High Life 32s while watching burlesque dancers at John Henry’s. In all seriousness though, High Life really isn’t that bad, fairly refreshing and though it does have a light corn flavor it’s not as noticable as it is in a lot of cheap lagers. Plus I have to give props to my friends Dave and Lemur, who are "High Life buddies".
Syrupy, nasty, cheap, American Pale Macro lager.  Can do better than this on a budget (ie. PBR).

I know this is blasphemous, RATEBEER being a classy website and all, but honestly, is there a better beer to have at a summer BBQ than Miller High Life?  I think not.  I can drink a million of these.  I think it must be the design of the bottle.  Once it hits your lips.  So good.

Miller High Life is excellent on tap, good out of the can, and poor (much of the time) out of the clear bottle.  On tap it’s smooth and creamy, and out of the can it’s an average mass-produced beer.  Good with popcorn, hot dogs & chili, and barbecue.  A classic run-of-the-mill American pale lager.  It’s okay, but stay away from that clear bottle!

RJT

Pours a clear pale yellow with a tall, chunky white head that has decent retention. Aroma is sweet barley, dry corn, dusty straw, a hint of grass and some cardboard. Flavor is grainy sweetness, some corn on the cob, a faint hint of grass and some leafy vegetal notes. Palate is thin slightly slick and highly carbonated. Overall this is a pretty average pale lager but seems to have less hops and more sweetness than most macros.

There’s little pleasant in the aroma: brown rice and stale beer farts. The beer itself is smooth with non-threatening flavors of malt and corn. Somehow, it’s refreshing. I can’t explain why I like it. Nothing about it is particularly good, but it’s enjoyable by the grill.
Very carbonated pale lager that is on par with the other American pale lagers.  Has something almost sweeter that I can’t put my finger on.  Not complex.
This beer was 50 cents a bottle at my favorite pool bar throughout college.  It got the job done. Super carbonated.
I drank this from the can while barbecueing.  It is a strangely sweet beer.  not overly offensive.  They get progressively harder to drink.
Easiest-drinking beer I’ve ever had. Champagne of beers? Maybe not, but definitely the perfect brew for the college crowd.

Today I had the task of running to Kingston and doing some shopping in Wal-Mart as the wife got her glasses fixed there.   I said to myself...Its hot out and I do need to mow the lawn....I looke at the shelf and saw a 12 pack of this for $5.25.   I used to like this stuff I thought... lets see how it fits in the gimballed cup holder on the lawn tractor.  Nose of wet corn sitting in the sun.  clear crisp golden in the lovely clear glass bottle.  refreshing in the sun and it does fit and ride nicely in the gimballed cup holder on the tractor.  Not horrible but not altogether great either.

Better than almost any other beer in its price range.  I’ve always found it drinkable, although not enjoyable.  Flavor is about what you would expect, with a little less burn than some similar brews.  If you’re on a budget, it will do.

20090522  12oz bottle, from the bottle, at Dreamland BBQ in Huntsville, AL.  Alright, I’ve had this a bunch of times in the past and this is one of the few macros I don’t mind buying on rare occasions.  Had it right from the bottle while I was waiting for my takeout order and it was admittedly drinkable and refreshing.  I stuck my nose in there but didn’t get much aroma and I’m not so sure I’ve ever had this in a glass, only from bottle or can.  I’ll call the aroma passable for now and give it an average score.  It was served appropriately ice cold so the flavor was clean, lightly bready, and slightly sour.  It didn’t taste bad, but it didn’t taste good either.  I gotta say, ice cold it drank pretty good on the day that Alabama Free the Hops enjoyed their great success and the law was changed allowing ’big’ beers into the state.  No ill effects, no bad aftertaste.  It was fine.
Bottle enjoyed at the Triple Rock after a 3 hours bike ride.  Yellow pour, no aroma, crisp and decent for what it is...a cheap American macro.
This beer isn’t very good, but it’s still better than Miller Lite. Anyone who actually thinks this is good is indeed living a high life, and should probably quit.

Can at the cyclones game.  Aroma is skunky with a bit of malts and corn coming out.  Taste is watered down and cheap.  For dollar beer night, I am not going to complain too much, but this is far from a good beer.

2009 22 oz can - I used to love this shit in college, but it gives me wicked headaches now, so I’m gonna stop after 22 oz...Pours light, clear yellow with a massive white head...aroma is sweet corn malt, faint lager skunk...flavour is very light and watery, sweet, with no real good or bad qualities besides the fact that is has no real qualities...how this is actually different from all the other lite miller beers is beyond me, I would assume the one tank goes to 3 differently branded bottling lines...
yellow pour. aroma and flavor both pretty non-descript, mostly corn and water. Great to pound like 15 of these, and a 6 pack of 16 ouncers is 4 bucks, but not much redeeming quality beyond that.
Pours yellow with a thin white head.  Smells of apple, corn, skunky.  Tastes swet and watery with a peppery splash on the finish.

Had this beer at a bar named Chaps in Sevierville, Tn.  I guess I was just in the mood for a pitcher of generic beer.  In any case, I thought it tasted better than what I thought it would.  Great clarity, light body, with a big foamy, white head.  Taste was mellow with a yeasty aftertaste.  I thought it was all in all good because I had 2 pitchers.  ;P

Aroma is corn with sweet undertones, and this brew has a beautiful golden hue to it. Sweetness dances around the tongue and the flavor finishes on a somewhat sour note. Body is light to medium, with a high amount of carbonation. Overall, the commercials are better than the brew; not bad, but not great.

Bottle at Holeman & Finch (served alongside a shot of Old Overholt Rye Whiskey, and together called "Buck the Recession", nice!).

The pour is yellow and bubbly with a surprisingly long-lasting white head that leaves a little bit of lacing.

The aroma is a little less impressive than the look, and is mostly corn and light sweet malts.

The taste follows the aroma and might have a little more flavor than I was expecting, with the sweetness of malts and grainy corn flavors.

The mouthfeel is medium bodied and certainly better than most BMC light beers out there.  It’s got a decent clean finish but leaves a bit of a sour taste in the mouth.

This is a middle of the road lager for the style, certainly not terrible but not one I’d want to drink very often.  It definitely tasted better after I had the shot of Old Overholt though.  Nice combo!
I think someone in the reviews wrote hint of corn, and I was thinking the same thing. Like a cheap bulk, plain, corn cereal. Refreshing, when you need something other than water. Could be much worse.

12 oz. bottle.  Pours a pale gold with a small, foamy white head.  Slight grain aroma.  Medium carbonation with a light mouthfeel.  Very light grain taste on the palate.  No discernable hops.  Very short finish.  What separates this beer apart is that there is nothing horribly terrible about it.  Very plain but refreshing.  You can certainly pick a worse macro.

Pours a pale yellow with a fluffy white head. Aroma is sort of musty, maybe hops??? That’s surprising. Then as is warms up just a degree, corn. Well that’s not that special. Musty corn and old hops. Don’t know if they even used barley in this boring little beer. Mmmm, I’m living the high life!
Seems to me to have a little more flavor then Miller light but that’s about all. It’s a good beer to get drunk on.
Regardless of the absolute lack of taste, depth, color, aroma, etc... I still love this beer!  I mean come on, it’s "The Champagne of Beers" after all....
About as "Plain Jane" as you can get. But I like it anyway. Decent all around beer. Good for those summer BBQ’S.
It’s cheaper than water and has a slight hint of corn.  Very carbonated, light bodied

Pours the color of urine.  Smells like urine with a hint of skunk spray.  taste of urine with a hint of corn.  Basically not good in anyway, but hell, it is the one of the bottom of the barrel brews at Miller, so if you expect anything different you are a fool.

Actually, the guy below me has the perfect review.  The pour is pale yellow, so clear it serves as a pretty good magnifying glass.  A fair sized white frothy head.  Grainy and corniful.  The beer has only a slight bite when ice cold (yes, it’s better ice cold) and gets syrupy and sweet when warming even a little.  I’m glad I got the 24 oz instead of the 40!

Appearance:  very pale yellow; white frothy head actually has above average head retention

Aroma:  not much of anything; slight grain and sweet corn

Flavor:  like stale corn; no hop presence; no hop bitterness; also lacks crispness, acidity, and/or sting 

Mouthfeel:  actually, a medium-light body

Minimal everything.  It is exactly what I expect from a major beer producer.  There is nothing bad with it but it does not excite any of the senses.  For cheap beer it will do.  If we could rate it with Clamato it would score much higher.
(bottle)  Pours a yellow color. Medium size white head. Mininal lacing. Aroma of light alcohol. Taste is watery, with light wheat/alcohol. Smooth/watery finish. Moderate carbonation.

I can see the Miller Brewery from my back yard. I shit you not. I’m not kidding. I can see the  Miller Brewery from my backyard. It’s a ways away, but I can see it. Which is why I am so GOD DAMNED embarrassed by this shit! Fake, marshmallow foam head. They use hop extract rather than regular hops (death penalty for that!) Death by burning!   This is crap @ any price!
My session beer. Cheap and slamable. Love them cans. Some corn flavor. Mostly water.

Not horrible for a cheap beer. It has a very clear pour with a white head that fades quickly. Taste has a hint of malts, no hop flavor, very watered down, but easy to drink if your not feeling a heavy beer.
Light yellow color with dicent head.  Aroma is of hay and corn.  Flavor is similar with some sweetness and a little bitter.  Not a bad beer, good for many macros
not that bad..nice classic beer.. not hard to drink.. depends on your mood i guess
The best of the American Big 3. That ain’t sayin’ much. This one is actually drnkable.
Not that bitter, not that bad.  For knowing what it is, and the cost, it is actually alright.
We have all seen and tried this beer. Nothing new to report. Pale yellow pour. Weak malts aroma with corn and grass. Flavor is weak. Watery body.

12z can pours a clear golden yellow with a foamy white head that disappears quickly. Smells of hay and wheat. Smooth sweet watery taste. Crisp and Refreshing.... Hey you know what? THIS DRANK PRITTY GOOD!!!!!!!

16 oz. can (part of a six pack) purchased at QFC in Mukilteo/Harbor Pointe, WA.  Pours a pale golden yellow with a thick foamy white head.  Flavor: Sweet malt, corn, and minimal hops...very smooth, and a decent macro brew.

the taste of the beer is a standard taste for one of the big beer company. The palate is light with not much there.  It’s agood fall back if you just want to wet your tounge.  I enjoy this beer on any given day.
Champagne or beers!?!?...more like champagne of crap. Find something else to drink.
It is a go to if you don’t have the money or the selection.  It is definitely a commercial beer, but of that class and price range, it is not unbearable.  I mean...it is High Life...

You know, its not terrible.  Not bad compared to other macros, but still not good.  Corn mash aroma, actual taste is there, not that its all good taste.  Can crink a bunch of these, but wouldn’t all too often.
Why did I just drink this....and out of a can no less? Because I simply felt like just guzzling a beer.....

Canned
Pale golden with a large, brief fluffy head.
Thin, sour, thin and sour.
Artificial maize.
Pure swill. Ashamed I ever drank the stuff. Beer has come a long way since the days that this was one of the few options available. Never again.

341ml bottle from an in-person trade with matt7215, thanks Matt. Pours a pale gold with a large white rocky and frothy head. Looks nice. Smells very faintly of some lemony hops drowned out by corn adjuncty macro-ness. Not impressive on the nose. Flavour is marginally better, same lemony hop presence drowned out big time by some grainy corny sweetness. ’Always smooth, never bitter’ is a pathetic lie of a marketing slogan. The one redeeming quality of this is its insanely mild but defintiely present bitterness. Finishes fizzy and watery with some dull macro adjuncty aspects that are at least tolerable. One of the ’better’ macro lagers I’ve had, but relatively speaking, and a pretty dubious distinction. I think I’d still go with a PBR if I had a gun held to my head. Thanks for the bottle Matt.

24 oz can drunk on the train on the way home from a very long day at work.  Tastes like cold, wet, fizzy water.  Sweetish with almost no bitterness or hop flavour at all.  What can I say... it tastes exactly like you’d imagine it tastes... which is to say nothing at all.

Champagne of beers? Yeah, maybe "champagne" in the "American Pie" sense. In case you missed that movie, I believe the layman’s term for it is "urine."  Can pours yellow with a white head.  Smells like a typical mediocre macro excuse for a beer.  Taste is corn and unpleasant bitterness.  Watery.
Bottle  Pours yellow with a white head.  Smells like cheap beer.  Taste like mass produced swill.  It is beer that is about all I can say.

can thanks to swalden28.  love the picture of the 40 oz.  poured a clear bubbly yellow with a white head.  aroma of corn and slight citrus.  flavor of corn and some funny aftertaste that i couldnt point out.  thin, watery, and high carbonation.

Isn’t there a reason breweries got rid of clear glass bottles?  None the less this brew rocks the trailer park.  Water overtakes any taste of malt, hops, but there is a twang that gives this the "high life".
Good for a mass brewed beer.  Very easy to drink. Light hops and malts in both the aroma and the taste.

Pours golden with a small fizzy white head. Aroma is of cardboard, corn, grain, and cheap beer malt. Taste is metallic, with delicous notes of wet cardboard, corn, grain, and malt. Goes down like water. It’s weak, but inoffensive in such a way that it’s good for getting drunk as hell. It does the job.

Out of all of the big company beers, this has to be my favorite.  I don’t like drinking light beer and anything other than a good IPA, bock, ale or good lager I don’t really touch the stuff, but if I have to, this is it.

341 ml bottle from TBS. i dont know what you were expecting but i got a hella drinkable pale lager. grainy but not overly sweet and this stuff goes down like water. really nothing to complain about or get excited about here. its macro swill with a touch of flavour.
